paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$(to ANTONIO) Look. He’s like a clock winding up to strike the hour.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$(to ALONSO) Sir—$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$(to ALONSO) Sir—$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$(to ANTONIO) One. Tell.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$(to ANTONIO) There he goes! Now we can tell what time it is.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$When every grief is entertained that’s offered,$NEWLINE$Comes to th' entertainer—
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$If we let every sad thing that happens to us get us down, then we would find ourselves—

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$A dollar.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$What a pain.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$Dolor comes to him, indeed. You have spoken truer than you purposed.
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$Pain, yes indeed. We would find ourselves in pain. You thought you were being funny, but you said the truth.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$You have taken it wiselier than I meant you should.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$You’re taking it more seriously than I meant it.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$(to ALONSO) Therefore, my lord—$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$(to ALONSO) Therefore, sir—$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$(to SEBASTIAN) Fie, what a spendthrift is he of his tongue!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$(to SEBASTIAN) God, doesn’t he ever shut up?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ALONSO$NEWLINE$(to GONZALO) I prithee, spare.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO$NEWLINE$(to GONZALO) Please, no more.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$Well, I have done. But yet—
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$Well, I’m nearly finished. But just one last thing—

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$(to ANTONIO) He will be talking.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$(to ANTONIO) He insists on talking.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Which, of he or Adrian, for a good wager, first begins to crow?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Hey, let’s bet. Which one will start yammering first, Gonzalo or Adrian?

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$The old cock.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$The old guy.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$The cockerel.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I pick the younger one.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Done. The wager?
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$You’re on. What’s the prize?

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$A laughter.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$A good laugh.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$A match!
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$It’s a deal!

paragraphs.original: ADRIAN$NEWLINE$Though this island seem to be desert—
paragraphs.translated: ADRIAN$NEWLINE$Though this island may appear desolate—

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$(to SEBASTIAN) Ha, ha, ha!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$(to SEBASTIAN) Ha, ha, ha!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$So you’re paid.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Fine, you win.

paragraphs.original: ADRIAN$NEWLINE$Uninhabitable and almost inaccessible—
paragraphs.translated: ADRIAN$NEWLINE$Uninhabitable and almost inaccessible, as it were—

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Yet—
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Now he’s going to say “but”—

paragraphs.original: ADRIAN$NEWLINE$Yet—
paragraphs.translated: ADRIAN$NEWLINE$But—

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$He could not miss ’t.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$He had to say it, it was unavoidable.

paragraphs.original: ADRIAN$NEWLINE$It must needs be of subtle, tender, and delicate temperance.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIAN$NEWLINE$The island must be mild, and have a temperate climate.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Temperance was a delicate wench.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I knew Temperance—she was a fine girl.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Ay, and a subtle, as he most learnedly delivered.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Yes, and she was mild too.

paragraphs.original: ADRIAN$NEWLINE$The air breathes upon us here most sweetly.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIAN$NEWLINE$There’s always a breath of fresh air here.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$As if it had lungs, and rotten ones.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$A breath from rotten lungs, maybe.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Or as ’twere perfumed by a fen.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Stinking like a swamp.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$Here is everything advantageous to life.
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$This island contains everything beneficial to life.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$True. Save means to live.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$True. Everything except something to live on.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Of that there’s none, or little.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$There’s little or nothing of that.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$How lush and lusty the grass looks! How green!
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$Look how lush and healthy the grass is! How green!

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$The ground indeed is tawny.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$The ground is brown.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$With an eye of green in ’t.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$With a touch of green in it.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$He misses not much.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$He doesn’t miss a thing.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$No, he doth but mistake the truth totally.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$No, he just gets reality completely wrong.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$But the rarity of it is—which is indeed almost beyond credit—
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$But the really unbelievable thing is—and this is incredible—

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$As many vouched rarities are.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$As most unbelievable things are.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$That our garments, being, as they were, drenched in the sea, hold notwithstanding their freshness and glosses, being rather new-dyed than stained with salt water.
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$That our clothes were drenched with sea water, but they came out looking brand-new.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$If but one of his pockets could speak, would it not say he lies?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Listen to him. If his clothes could talk, they’d call him a liar.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Ay, or very falsely pocket up his report.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Or stuff what he says into their pockets.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$Methinks our garments are now as fresh as when we put them on first in Afric, at the marriage of the king’s fair daughter Claribel to the King of Tunis.
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$Seriously, I think our clothes are as fresh now as they were the day we put them on in Africa, when we attended the marriage of the king’s daughter Claribel to the King of Tunis.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$'Twas a sweet marriage, and we prosper well in our return.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$It was a lovely wedding, and we’re doing really well on our trip home.

paragraphs.original: ADRIAN$NEWLINE$Tunis was never graced before with such a paragon to their queen.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIAN$NEWLINE$Tunis has never had such a beautiful queen.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$Not since widow Dido’s time.
paragraphs.translated:
GONZALO$NEWLINE$Not since the days of widow
Dido.$NEWLINE$Dido$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Widow! A pox o' that! How came that “widow” in? Widow Dido!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Widow? Why the hell is he calling her “widow Dido”?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$What if he had said “widower Æneas” too? Good Lord, how you take it!
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Next thing you know, he’ll be saying “widower Aeneas.”

paragraphs.original: ADRIAN$NEWLINE$“Widow Dido” said you? You make me study of that. She was of Carthage, not of Tunis.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIAN$NEWLINE$“Widow Dido,” did you say? I’m not sure about that. Dido was from Carthage, not Tunis.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$This Tunis, sir, was Carthage.
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$Tunis was Carthage, sir.$NEWLINE$Tunis$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$was

paragraphs.original: ADRIAN$NEWLINE$Carthage?
paragraphs.translated: ADRIAN$NEWLINE$Carthage?

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$I assure you, Carthage.
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$I’m telling you, it was Carthage.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$His word is more than the miraculous harp. He hath raised the wall and houses too.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Gonzalo is a miracle-worker. If he says Carthage was here, then Carthage must be here.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$What impossible matter will he make easy next?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$What miracle will he work next?

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I think he will carry this island home in his pocket and give it his son for an apple.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I think he’ll carry this island home in his pocket and give it to his son like an apple.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$And sowing the kernels of it in the sea, bring forth more islands.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$And then throw the seeds in the sea, to make more islands grow.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$Ay.
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$Yes indeed.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Why, in good time.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Absolutely, yes indeed.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$(to ALONSO) Sir, we were talking that our garments seem now as fresh as when we were at Tunis at the marriage of your daughter, who is now queen.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$(to ALONSO) Sir, we were saying that our clothes seem just as fresh as they did when we attended the wedding of your daughter, who’s now queen of Tunis.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$And the rarest that e'er came there.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$The most beautiful queen they ever had.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Bate, I beseech you, widow Dido.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I beg your pardon, except for the widow Dido.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Oh, widow Dido? Ay, widow Dido.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Oh, except for the widow Dido? That’s right, except for the widow Dido.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$Is not, sir, my doublet as fresh as the first day I wore it? I mean, in a sort.
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$Isn’t my vest just as clean and fresh as the day I put it on? In a way, I mean.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$That “sort” was well fished for.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$“In a way” is the right way to go.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$When I wore it at your daughter’s marriage?
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$I mean when I wore it at your daughter’s wedding.

paragraphs.original: ALONSO$NEWLINE$You cram these words into mine ears against$NEWLINE$The stomach of my sense. Would I had never$NEWLINE$Married my daughter there! For, coming thence,$NEWLINE$My son is lost and, in my rate, she too,$NEWLINE$Who is so far from Italy removed$NEWLINE$I ne'er again shall see her.—O thou mine heir$NEWLINE$Of Naples and of Milan, what strange fish$NEWLINE$Hath made his meal on thee?
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO$NEWLINE$You keep cramming words into my ears that I don’t want to hear. I wish that wedding had never happened, since I lost my son because of it, and I lost my daughter too in a way, since she’s moved so far from Milan that I’ll never see her again.—Oh, dear son of mine and heir of Naples and Milan, what strange fish has made a meal of you?

paragraphs.original: FRANCISCO$NEWLINE$Sir, he may live.$NEWLINE$I saw him beat the surges under him,$NEWLINE$And ride upon their backs. He trod the water,$NEWLINE$Whose enmity he flung aside, and breasted$NEWLINE$The surge most swoll'n that met him. His bold head$NEWLINE$'Bove the contentious waves he kept, and oared$NEWLINE$Himself with his good arms in lusty stroke$NEWLINE$To th' shore, that o'er his wave-worn basis bowed,$NEWLINE$As stooping to relieve him. I not doubt$NEWLINE$He came alive to land.
paragraphs.translated: FRANCISCO$NEWLINE$Sir, he may still be alive. I saw him swimming strongly, almost as if he was riding the waves. He treaded water and kept his head well above the wild waters coming at him, swimming with his strong arms toward the shore, which almost seemed eager to welcome him. I have no doubt he got ashore alive.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ALONSO$NEWLINE$No, no, he’s gone.
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO$NEWLINE$No, no, he’s dead.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Sir, you may thank yourself for this great loss,$NEWLINE$That would not bless our Europe with your daughter,$NEWLINE$But rather loose her to an African,$NEWLINE$Where she at least is banished from your eye,$NEWLINE$Who hath cause to wet the grief on ’t.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Sir, you can thank yourself for this great loss, because you wouldn’t bless Europe with your daughter, but instead pimped her out to an African. At least you can be thankful that she won’t be around to remind you of your loss.

paragraphs.original: ALONSO$NEWLINE$Prithee, peace.
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO$NEWLINE$Please be quiet.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$You were kneeled to and importuned otherwise$NEWLINE$By all of us, and the fair soul herself$NEWLINE$Weighed between loathness and obedience, at$NEWLINE$Which end o' th' beam should bow. We have lost your son,$NEWLINE$I fear, forever. Milan and Naples have$NEWLINE$More widows in them of this business' making$NEWLINE$Than we bring men to comfort them.$NEWLINE$The fault’s your own.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$We all begged you not to go ahead with those marriage plans, and your lovely daughter struggled between disgust at marrying an African and the desire to obey you. Now I’m afraid we’ve lost your son forever. Our shipwreck has made more women widows in Milan and Naples than there are survivors to comfort them. And it’s all your fault.

paragraphs.original: ALONSO$NEWLINE$So is the dearest o' th' loss.
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO$NEWLINE$And the greatest sorrow is mine too.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$My lord Sebastian,$NEWLINE$The truth you speak doth lack some gentleness$NEWLINE$And time to speak it in. You rub the sore$NEWLINE$When you should bring the plaster.
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$My lord Sebastian, even though what you say is true, your way of saying it is tactless and comes at the wrong time. You’re rubbing salt in his wounds when you should be applying bandages.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Very well.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$All right, I’ll stop.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$And most chirurgeonly.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Like a good doctor.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$(to ALONSO) It is foul weather in us all, good sir,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$When you are cloudy.
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$(to ALONSO) It’s bad times for all of us, sir, when you’re feeling gloomy.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Foul weather?
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Bad times?

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Very foul.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Yes, very bad.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$Had I plantation of this isle, my lord—
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$If I could colonize this island, my lord—

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$He’d sow ’t with nettle seed.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$He’d cultivate weeds on it.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Or docks, or mallows.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Or thorn-bushes.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$And were the king on ’t, what would I do?
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$And if I were king of it, you know what I’d do?

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$'Scape being drunk for want of wine.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$He wouldn’t get drunk much, since there’s no wine here.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$I' th' commonwealth I would by contraries$NEWLINE$Execute all things. For no kind of traffic$NEWLINE$Would I admit. No name of magistrate.$NEWLINE$Letters should not be known. Riches, poverty,$NEWLINE$And use of service—none. Contract, succession,$NEWLINE$Bourn, bound of land, tilth, vineyard—none.$NEWLINE$No use of metal, corn, or wine, or oil.$NEWLINE$No occupation. All men idle, all.$NEWLINE$And women too, but innocent and pure.$NEWLINE$No sovereignty—
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$In my kingdom I’d do everything differently from the way it’s usually done. I wouldn’t allow any commerce. There’d be no officials or administrators. There’d be no schooling or literature. There’d be no riches, no poverty, and no servants—none. No contracts or inheritance laws; no division of the land into private farms, no metal-working, agriculture, or vineyards.$NEWLINE$There’d be no work. Men would have nothing to do, and women also—but they’d be innocent and pure. There’d be no kingship—

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Yet he would be king on ’t.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$He wants to be king in a place with no kingship.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$The latter end of his commonwealth forgets the beginning.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Yes, he’s getting a bit confused.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$All things in common nature should produce$NEWLINE$Without sweat or endeavor. Treason, felony,$NEWLINE$Sword, pike, knife, gun, or need of any engine,$NEWLINE$Would I not have. But nature should bring forth$NEWLINE$Of its own kind all foison, all abundance,$NEWLINE$To feed my innocent people.
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$Everything would be produced without labor, and would be shared by all. There’d be no treason, crimes, or weapons. Nature would produce its harvests in abundance, to feed my innocent people.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$No marrying ’mong his subjects?
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$There’d be no marriage?

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$None, man. All idle. Whores and knaves.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$No. Everyone would have nothing to do. They’d all be whores and slackers.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$I would with such perfection govern, sir,$NEWLINE$T' excel the Golden Age.
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$I would rule so perfectly that my country would outshine the Golden Age they had in ancient times.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$'Save his majesty!
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Long live his Majesty!

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Long live Gonzalo!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$All hail Gonzalo!

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$(to ALONSO)     And—do you mark me, sir?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$(to ALONSO) Are you listening to me, sir?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ALONSO$NEWLINE$Prithee, no more. Thou dost talk nothing to me.
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO$NEWLINE$Oh, please be quiet. You’re spouting empty words.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$I do well believe your highness, and did it to minister occasion to these gentlemen, who are of such sensible and nimble lungs that they always use to laugh at nothing.
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$You’re absolutely right, your highness. I talked like that to give these gentlemen here a chance to have a good laugh. They love to laugh at empty words.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$'Twas you we laughed at.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$It’s you we were laughing at.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$Who in this kind of merry fooling am nothing to you. So you may continue and laugh at nothing still.
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$But from your perspective I don’t matter, so I’m just an empty nobody for you. Go ahead and laugh at my empty words some more.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$What a blow was there given!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Ouch, what a comeback!

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$An it had not fallen flat-long.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$He sure did. Too bad it fell flat.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$You are gentlemen of brave mettle. You would lift the moon out of her sphere if she would continue in it five weeks without changing.
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$You’re brave gentlemen. You’d give the moon a shove if it got stuck five weeks in its orbit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ARIEL invisible, playing solemn music$NEWLINE$ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL enters, invisible, playing solemn music.$NEWLINE$ARIEL

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$We would so, and then go a-batfowling.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$That’s right, and then after we fixed the moon, we’d go bird-hunting.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$(to GONZALO) Nay, good my lord, be not angry.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$(to GONZALO) Don’t be angry with us, my lord.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$No, I warrant you. I will not adventure my discretion so weakly. Will you laugh me asleep, for I am very heavy?
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$I’m not. I’ve got good judgment, and I know you’ve got nothing against me. Will you laugh me to sleep? I’m feeling very sleepy.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Go sleep, and hear us.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Go to sleep, and listen to us laughing.

paragraphs.original: All sleep except ALONSO, SEBASTIAN, and ANTONIO$NEWLINE$ALONSO$NEWLINE$SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$ANTONIO
paragraphs.translated: Everyone sleeps except ALONSO, SEBASTIAN, and ANTONIO.$NEWLINE$ALONSO$NEWLINE$SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$ANTONIO

paragraphs.original: ALONSO$NEWLINE$What, all so soon asleep? I wish mine eyes$NEWLINE$Would with themselves shut up my thoughts. I find$NEWLINE$They are inclined to do so.
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO$NEWLINE$What, everybody falls asleep so fast? I wish I could sleep too—it would stop me from thinking. Come to think of it, I am feeling sleepy.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Please you, sir,$NEWLINE$Do not omit the heavy offer of it.$NEWLINE$It seldom visits sorrow. When it doth,$NEWLINE$It is a comforter.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$In that case you should sleep. People in grief need a good sleep. It doesn’t come to them often, but when it does come they should enjoy it.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$We two, my lord,$NEWLINE$Will guard your person while you take your rest$NEWLINE$And watch your safety.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$The two of us will guard you while you sleep, my lord, and keep you safe.

paragraphs.original: ALONSO$NEWLINE$Thank you. Wondrous heavy.
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO$NEWLINE$Thank you. I’m terribly sleepy.

paragraphs.original: (falls asleep)
paragraphs.translated: He falls asleep.

paragraphs.original: Exit ARIEL$NEWLINE$ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL exits.$NEWLINE$ARIEL

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$What a strange drowsiness possesses them!
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$How strange that they all got so sleepy!

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$It is the quality o' th' climate.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$There must be something in the air here.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Why$NEWLINE$Doth it not then our eyelids sink? I find not$NEWLINE$Myself disposed to sleep.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$So why aren’t our eyelids heavy? I’m not sleepy at all.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Nor I. My spirits are nimble.$NEWLINE$They fell together all, as by consent.$NEWLINE$They dropped, as by a thunderstroke. What might,$NEWLINE$Worthy Sebastian, O, what might—? No more.—$NEWLINE$And yet methinks I see it in thy face,$NEWLINE$What thou shouldst be. Th' occasion speaks thee, and$NEWLINE$My strong imagination sees a crown$NEWLINE$Dropping upon thy head.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Me neither. I’m wide awake. They all fell asleep together, as if they’d planned it. Like they’d all been struck by lightning. What might happen, Sebastian, what might happen if—No, it’s time for me to shut up.— But still, I think I can see in your face what you ought to be. Opportunity’s knocking for you, and in my imagination I see a crown dropping onto your head.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$What, art thou waking?
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Are you dreaming or awake?

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Do you not hear me speak?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Don’t you hear me speaking?

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I do, and surely$NEWLINE$It is a sleepy language, and thou speak’st$NEWLINE$Out of thy sleep. What is it thou didst say?$NEWLINE$This is a strange repose, to be asleep$NEWLINE$With eyes wide open, standing, speaking, moving,$NEWLINE$And yet so fast asleep.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I do, and it sounds like you’re talking in your sleep. What did you say? It’s weird for you to be dreaming with your eyes wide open—standing, talking, moving, but sound asleep.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Noble Sebastian,$NEWLINE$Thou let’st thy fortune sleep—die, rather—wink’st$NEWLINE$Whiles thou art waking.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Good Sebastian, you’re the one who’s sleeping if you let this opportunity pass you by without acting on it.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Thou dost snore distinctly.$NEWLINE$There’s meaning in thy snores.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$You’re snoring, but it sounds like you’re talking. There’s meaning in your snoring.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I am more serious than my custom. You$NEWLINE$Must be so too if heed me, which to do$NEWLINE$Trebles thee o'er.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I’m not kidding when I say this, I’m not joking around like usual. You should be serious too when you listen to what I’m saying. You can become a great man if you listen to me.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Well, I am standing water.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I’m hanging on every word you say.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I’ll teach you how to flow.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$You need to do more than hang around—you have to act. I’ll show you how.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Do so. To ebb$NEWLINE$Hereditary sloth instructs me.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$You need to. I’m lazy by nature.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Oh,$NEWLINE$If you but knew how you the purpose cherish$NEWLINE$Whiles thus you mock it! How, in stripping it,$NEWLINE$You more invest it! Ebbing men indeed$NEWLINE$Most often do so near the bottom run$NEWLINE$By their own fear or sloth.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Oh, if you only knew how close to success you are, even while you make fun of what I’m telling you! The more you joke about it, the more clearly I feel how serious it is! Lazy people end up at the bottom, and you deserve to be at the top.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Prithee, say on.$NEWLINE$The setting of thine eye and cheek proclaim$NEWLINE$A matter from thee, and a birth indeed$NEWLINE$Which throes thee much to yield.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Please, tell me more. There’s something in your expression that tells me you have something serious to say, and you’re having a lot of difficulty saying it.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Thus, sir:$NEWLINE$Although this lord of weak remembrance—this,$NEWLINE$Who shall be of as little memory$NEWLINE$When he is earthed—hath here almost persuade$NEWLINE$(For he’s a spirit of persuasion only,$NEWLINE$Professes to persuade) the king his son’s alive,$NEWLINE$'Tis as impossible that he’s undrowned$NEWLINE$And he that sleeps here swims.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$This is what I’m saying. (points at GONZALO) Although this lord who has such a bad memory—and who will be forgotten by the world when he’s dead and buried—almost succeeded in convincing the king that his son’s alive, it’s impossible that he survived. It’s as far from the truth as saying this sleeping man is swimming.$NEWLINE$(points at$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I have no hope$NEWLINE$That he’s undrowned.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Yes, I’m sure he’s dead. I’ve got no hope that he survived.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Oh, out of that “no hope”$NEWLINE$What great hope have you! No hope that way is$NEWLINE$Another way so high a hope that even$NEWLINE$Ambition cannot pierce a wink beyond,$NEWLINE$But doubt discovery there. Will you grant with me$NEWLINE$That Ferdinand is drowned?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$But in that “no hope” there are great hopes for you! That “no hope” means you’re on the way to glory so brilliant you couldn’t even imagine it, no matter how ambitious you were. Do you agree that Ferdinand must have drowned?

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$He’s gone.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$He’s dead.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Then, tell me,$NEWLINE$Who’s the next heir of Naples?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$So, in that case, tell me who’s next in line to inherit the kingdom of Naples?

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Claribel.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Claribel, his daughter.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$She that is Queen of Tunis; she that dwells$NEWLINE$Ten leagues beyond man’s life; she that from Naples$NEWLINE$Can have no note, unless the sun were post—$NEWLINE$The man i' th' moon’s too slow—till newborn chins$NEWLINE$Be rough and razorable; she that from whom$NEWLINE$We all were sea-swallowed, though some cast again,$NEWLINE$And by that destiny to perform an act$NEWLINE$Whereof what’s past is prologue, what to come$NEWLINE$In yours and my discharge.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$The one who’s now Queen of Tunis, living at the edge of the world, out of reach of mail service. It takes a letter longer to reach her than it takes a baby boy to grow old enough to shave. Claribel who was the cause of our shipwreck, which a few of us survived—she was destined to give us an opportunity that we are destined to act on.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$What stuff is this? How say you?$NEWLINE$'Tis true, my brother’s daughter’s Queen of Tunis,$NEWLINE$So is she heir of Naples, ’twixt which regions$NEWLINE$There is some space.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$What in the world are you talking about? It’s true that my brother’s daughter is Queen of Tunis, and heir of Naples. And it’s true those two places are far apart.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$A space whose every cubit$NEWLINE$Seems to cry out, “How shall that Claribel$NEWLINE$Measure us back to Naples? Keep in Tunis,
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$So far that every foot of distance between them seems to shout, “It’s too far for Claribel to come back to Naples. Let her stay in Tunis and give Sebastian a

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And let Sebastian wake.” Say this were death$NEWLINE$That now hath seized them. Why, they were no worse$NEWLINE$Than now they are. There be that can rule Naples$NEWLINE$As well as he that sleeps, lords that can prate$NEWLINE$As amply and unnecessarily$NEWLINE$As this Gonzalo. I myself could make$NEWLINE$A chough of as deep chat. Oh, that you bore$NEWLINE$The mind that I do, what a sleep were this$NEWLINE$For your advancement! Do you understand me?
paragraphs.translated: chance to start living.” If these sleeping men were dead instead of sleeping, they’d be no worse off than they are now. There are a lot of men who can rule Naples just as well as this sleeping guy here can. There are a lot of men who babble nonsense as well as Gonzalo. I could do it myself. Oh, I wish you understood what I’m saying—you’d see how you’re missing out on a great opportunity for yourself! Do you even get what I’m saying?

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Methinks I do.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I think I do.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$And how does your content$NEWLINE$Tender your own good fortune?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$And does this prospect of good fortune make you happy?

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I remember$NEWLINE$You did supplant your brother Prospero.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I remember you took the throne from your brother Prospero.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$True.$NEWLINE$And look how well my garments sit upon me,$NEWLINE$Much feater than before. My brother’s servants$NEWLINE$Were then my fellows. Now they are my men.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Yes I did, and look how good I look in my new role—much better than before. My brother’s servants used to be my equals. Now they work for me.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$But, for your conscience?
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$But what about your guilty conscience?

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Ay, sir. Where lies that? If ’twere a kibe,$NEWLINE$'Twould put me to my slipper. But I feel not$NEWLINE$This deity in my bosom. Twenty consciences,$NEWLINE$That stand ’twixt me and Milan, candied be they$NEWLINE$And melt ere they molest! Here lies your brother,$NEWLINE$No better than the earth he lies upon,$NEWLINE$If he were that which now he’s like—that’s dead—$NEWLINE$Whom I, with this obedient steel, three inches of it,$NEWLINE$Can lay to bed for ever; whiles you, doing thus,$NEWLINE$To the perpetual wink for aye might put$NEWLINE$This ancient morsel, this Sir Prudence, who
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Yes. What guilty conscience? I don’t feel anything. If my feet were cold, I’d put my slippers on, but I don’t feel any pangs of guilt. If there were twenty guilty consciences between me and the dukedom, they’d melt away to nothing before they caused me any trouble. Here’s your brother sleeping, worth no more than the dirt he’s lying on. If he were as dead as he appears to be now—and I could quickly make him dead with this sword of mine—he wouldn’t stand in our way. As

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Should not upbraid our course. For all the rest,$NEWLINE$They’ll take suggestion as a cat laps milk.$NEWLINE$They’ll tell the clock to any business that$NEWLINE$We say befits the hour.
paragraphs.translated: for the other men, we can make them believe anything we choose. They’ll set their watches to whatever time we say.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Thy case, dear friend,$NEWLINE$Shall be my precedent. As thou got’st Milan,$NEWLINE$I’ll come by Naples. Draw thy sword. One stroke$NEWLINE$Shall free thee from the tribute which thou payest.$NEWLINE$And I the king shall love thee.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$You’ll be my role model. Just as you got Milan, I’ll get Naples. Take out your sword. With one cut you can be through paying money to Naples. And as king I’ll love you forever.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Draw together.$NEWLINE$And when I rear my hand, do you the like,$NEWLINE$To fall it on Gonzalo.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$You take out your sword too. When I raise my hand, you do the same, and bring it down on Gonzalo’s head.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO and SEBASTIAN draw their swords$NEWLINE$ANTONIO$NEWLINE$SEBASTIAN
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO and SEBASTIAN take out their swords.$NEWLINE$ANTONIO$NEWLINE$SEBASTIAN

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$O, but one word.$NEWLINE$(speaks quietly to ANTONIO)$NEWLINE$(speaks quietly to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Oh, but there’s one more thing to tell you. (he speaks quietly to ANTONIO)$NEWLINE$(he speaks quietly to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Enter ARIEL invisible, with music and song$NEWLINE$ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL enters, invisible, singing and playing music.$NEWLINE$ARIEL

paragraphs.original: ARIEL$NEWLINE$(to GONZALO) My master through his art foresees the danger$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$That you, his friend, are, and sends me forth—$NEWLINE$For else his project dies—to keep them living.$NEWLINE$(sings in GONZALO ’s ear)$NEWLINE$(sings in$NEWLINE$’s ear)$NEWLINE$While you here do snoring lie,$NEWLINE$While you here do snoring lie$NEWLINE$Open-eyed conspiracy$NEWLINE$Open-eyed conspiracy$NEWLINE$His time doth take.$NEWLINE$His time doth take$NEWLINE$If of life you keep a care,$NEWLINE$If of life you keep a care$NEWLINE$Shake off slumber and beware.$NEWLINE$Shake off slumber and beware$NEWLINE$Awake, awake!$NEWLINE$Awake, awake!
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL$NEWLINE$(to GONZALO) With his magic powers my master can see the dangers that you are in, my friend. So he sent me to make sure these men survive—and to guarantee his plans succeed. (sings in GONZALO ’s ear)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(sings in$NEWLINE$’s ear)$NEWLINE$While you lie here snoring,$NEWLINE$While you lie here snoring,$NEWLINE$Men are plotting against you.$NEWLINE$Men are plotting against you.$NEWLINE$If you want to stay alive,$NEWLINE$If you want to stay alive,$NEWLINE$Wake up and beware.$NEWLINE$Wake up and beware.$NEWLINE$Wake up, wake up!$NEWLINE$Wake up, wake up!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Then let us both be sudden.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Let’s act quickly.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$(waking and seeing them)$NEWLINE$(waking and seeing them)$NEWLINE$Now, good angels preserve the king!
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$(waking and seeing them) God help the king! Save him!$NEWLINE$(waking and seeing them)

paragraphs.original: ALONSO$NEWLINE$(waking) Why, how now? Ho, awake!$NEWLINE$(waking)
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO$NEWLINE$(waking up) Hey, what’s this, what’s going on? Wake up!$NEWLINE$(waking up)

paragraphs.original: All wake
paragraphs.translated: Everyone wakes up.

paragraphs.original: Why are you drawn?$NEWLINE$Wherefore this ghastly looking?
paragraphs.translated: Why are your swords out? Why do you look like that?

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$What’s the matter?
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$What’s this all about?

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$Whiles we stood here securing your repose,$NEWLINE$Even now, we heard a hollow burst of bellowing$NEWLINE$Like bulls, or rather lions. Did ’t not wake you?$NEWLINE$It struck mine ear most terribly.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$While we were here guarding you as you slept, we heard a loud roar that sounded like bulls, or lions. Didn’t you hear it? We heard it very clearly.

paragraphs.original: ALONSO$NEWLINE$I heard nothing.
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO$NEWLINE$I didn’t hear anything.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Oh, ’twas a din to fright a monster’s ear,$NEWLINE$To make an earthquake! Sure, it was the roar$NEWLINE$Of a whole herd of lions.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Oh, it was a monstrous roar, to make the earth tremble! I’m sure there was a herd of lions nearby.

paragraphs.original: ALONSO$NEWLINE$Heard you this, Gonzalo?
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO$NEWLINE$Did you hear this, Gonzalo?

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$Upon mine honor, sir, I heard a humming,$NEWLINE$And that a strange one too, which did awake me.$NEWLINE$I shaked you, sir, and cried. As mine eyes opened,$NEWLINE$I saw their weapons drawn. There was a noise,$NEWLINE$That’s verily. 'Tis best we stand upon our guard,$NEWLINE$Or that we quit this place. Let’s draw our weapons.
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$It’s true I heard a humming sound, a strange one, which woke me up. I shook you and shouted at you, sir. When I opened my eyes, I saw their swords out. There was a noise, that’s certainly true. We should either be on guard here constantly or move to a different camp. Let’s draw our own swords too.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ALONSO$NEWLINE$Lead off this ground, and let’s make further search$NEWLINE$For my poor son.
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO$NEWLINE$Lead us away from this area. We can search for my poor son while we’re at it.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$Heavens keep him from these beasts!$NEWLINE$For he is, sure, i' th' island.
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$I hope those lions stay far away from him. I’m sure he’s somewhere on the island.

paragraphs.original: ALONSO$NEWLINE$Lead away.
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO$NEWLINE$Get us out of here.

paragraphs.original: ARIEL$NEWLINE$(aside) Prospero my lord shall know what I have done.$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$So, King, go safely on to seek thy son.
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL$NEWLINE$(to himself) My lord Prospero will know what I’ve done. So go ahead, King, and look for your son.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CALIBAN with a burden of wood A noise of thunder heard$NEWLINE$CALIBAN
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN enters with a load of wood. A noise of thunder is heard.$NEWLINE$CALIBAN

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$All the infections that the sun sucks up$NEWLINE$From bogs, fens, flats, on Prosper fall and make him$NEWLINE$By inchmeal a disease! His spirits hear me$NEWLINE$And yet I needs must curse. But they’ll nor pinch,$NEWLINE$Fright me with urchin-shows, pitch me i' th' mire,$NEWLINE$Nor lead me like a firebrand in the dark$NEWLINE$Out of my way, unless he bid 'em. But$NEWLINE$For every trifle are they set upon me,$NEWLINE$Sometime like apes that mow and chatter at me,$NEWLINE$And after bite me, then like hedgehogs which$NEWLINE$Lie tumbling in my barefoot way and mount$NEWLINE$Their pricks at my footfall. Sometime am I$NEWLINE$All wound with adders who with cloven tongues$NEWLINE$Do hiss me into madness.
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$I hope all the diseases that breed in swamps and marshes infect Prospero, inch by inch, until he’s nothing but a walking disease! His spirits are listening to me, but I can’t help cursing him anyway. They won’t pinch me, frighten me, push me in the mud, or mislead me unless he tells them to. But he sends them to punish me for every little thing. Sometimes his spirits take the form of apes, grimacing and chattering at me and then biting me; sometimes they come like porcupines, my feet as I walk. Sometimes snakes wrap around me, hissing at me with their forked tongues till I go crazy.

paragraphs.original: Enter TRINCULO$NEWLINE$TRINCULO
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO enters.$NEWLINE$TRINCULO

paragraphs.original: Lo, now, lo!$NEWLINE$Here comes a spirit of his, and to torment me$NEWLINE$For bringing wood in slowly. I’ll fall flat.$NEWLINE$Perchance he will not mind me.$NEWLINE$(lies down, covered by his gaberdine)$NEWLINE$(lies down, covered by his gaberdine)
paragraphs.translated: Hey, look over there! Here comes one of his spirits to torture me for taking so long to bring the wood back. I’ll lie down and hide. Maybe he won’t see me. (he lies down and covers himself with his cloak)$NEWLINE$(he lies down and covers himself with his cloak)

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Here’s neither bush nor shrub to bear off any weather at all.$NEWLINE$And another storm brewing, I hear it sing i' th' wind. Yond same black cloud, yond huge one, looks like a foul bombard that would shed his liquor. If it should thunder as it did before, I know not where to hide my head. Yond same cloud cannot choose but fall by pailfuls. (sees CALIBAN)$NEWLINE$(sees$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$There are no bushes or shrubs to protect me from the weather here. And there’s another storm brewing—I can hear it in the way the wind whistles. That huge black cloud over there looks like a filthy liquor jug that’s about to pour out its contents. It won’t be able to help pouring rain down by the bucket-full. (he sees CALIBAN)$NEWLINE$(he sees$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: What have we here? A man or a fish? Dead or alive? A fish. He smells like a fish, a very ancient and fish-like smell, a kind of not-of-the-newest poor-john. A strange fish! Were I in England now, as once I was, and had but this fish painted, not a holiday fool there but would give a piece of silver. There would this monster make a man. Any strange beast there makes a man. When they will not give a doit to relieve a lame beggar, they will lay out ten to see a dead Indian. Legged like a man and his fins like arms! Warm, o' my troth. I do now let loose my opinion, hold it no longer: this is no fish, but an islander that hath lately suffered by a thunderbolt.
paragraphs.translated: What do we have here, a man or a fish? Whew, he stinks like a fish—an old salted fish, not a fresh-caught one. A strange fish. If I were in England now, like I was once, and I had even a painted picture of this fish, every fool there would give me a piece of silver to look at it. In England this strange monster would be just like a man. Any strange beast there can be considered a man. The men there won’t give a penny to a lame beggar, but they’ll pay ten cents to look at a freak show exhibit. This guy has legs like a man but fins for arms! And he’s still warm, by God. I guess this is not a fish, but a native who got struck by lightning just now.

paragraphs.original: Thunder
paragraphs.translated: Thunder.

paragraphs.original: Alas, the storm is come again! My best way is to creep under his gaberdine. There is no other shelter hereabouts. Misery acquaints a man with strange bedfellows. I will here shroud till the dregs of the storm be past.$NEWLINE$(crawls under gaberdine)$NEWLINE$(crawls under gaberdine)
paragraphs.translated: Oh, here comes the storm again. The best thing to do is crawl under his cloak. There’s no other shelter around here. In emergencies you meet the strangest folks. I’ll just stay here till the storm passes. (he crawls under CALIBAN ’s cloak)$NEWLINE$(he crawls under$NEWLINE$’s cloak)

paragraphs.original: Enter STEPHANO, singing$NEWLINE$STEPHANO
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO enters, singing.$NEWLINE$STEPHANO

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$I shall no more to sea, to sea,$NEWLINE$I shall no more to sea, to sea$NEWLINE$Here shall I die ashore—$NEWLINE$Here shall I die ashore$NEWLINE$This is a very scurvy tune to sing at a man’s funeral.$NEWLINE$Well, here’s my comfort. (drinks, sings)$NEWLINE$(drinks, sings)$NEWLINE$The master, the swabber, the boatswain, and I,$NEWLINE$The master, the swabber, the boatswain, and I$NEWLINE$The gunner and his mate$NEWLINE$The gunner and his mate$NEWLINE$Loved Mall, Meg, and Marian, and Margery,$NEWLINE$Loved Mall, Meg, and Marian, and Margery$NEWLINE$But none of us cared for Kate.$NEWLINE$But none of us cared for Kate$NEWLINE$For she had a tongue with a tang,$NEWLINE$For she had a tongue with a tang
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$I’ll never go to sea again,$NEWLINE$I’ll never go to sea again,$NEWLINE$I’ll die here on shore—$NEWLINE$I’ll die here on shore—$NEWLINE$This is a rotten song to sing at a man’s funeral. At least I’ve got some booze to comfort me. (he drinks and sings)$NEWLINE$(he drinks and sings)$NEWLINE$The master, the deck-washer, the boatswain, and I,$NEWLINE$The master, the deck-washer, the boatswain, and I,$NEWLINE$The gunman and his friend,$NEWLINE$The gunman and his friend,$NEWLINE$We loved Moll, Meg, Marian, and Margery$NEWLINE$We loved Moll, Meg, Marian, and Margery$NEWLINE$But none of us cared for Kate.$NEWLINE$But none of us cared for Kate.$NEWLINE$Kate had a gutter mouth,$NEWLINE$Kate had a gutter mouth,

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Would cry to a sailor, “Go hang!”$NEWLINE$Would cry to a sailor, “Go hang!”$NEWLINE$She loved not the savor of tar nor of pitch,$NEWLINE$She loved not the savor of tar nor of pitch$NEWLINE$Yet a tailor might scratch her where'er she did itch.$NEWLINE$Yet a tailor might scratch her where'er she did itch$NEWLINE$Then to sea, boys, and let her go hang!$NEWLINE$Then to sea, boys, and let her go hang!$NEWLINE$This is a scurvy tune too. But here’s my comfort.$NEWLINE$This is a scurvy tune too. But here’s my comfort
paragraphs.translated: And would shout to sailors, “Go to hell!”$NEWLINE$And would shout to sailors, “Go to hell!”$NEWLINE$She didn’t like ship smells like tar,$NEWLINE$She didn’t like ship smells like tar,$NEWLINE$But liked it okay when a tailor took her to bed.$NEWLINE$But liked it okay when a tailor took her to bed$NEWLINE$So go to sea, boys, and let her go to hell!$NEWLINE$So go to sea, boys, and let her go to hell!$NEWLINE$That’s a rotten song too. But here’s something to comfort me.$NEWLINE$That’s a rotten song too. But here’s something to comfort me.

paragraphs.original: (drinks)
paragraphs.translated: (he drinks)

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Do not torment me. Oh!
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Don’t hurt me. Oh!

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$What’s the matter? Have we devils here? Do you put tricks upon ’s with savages and men of Ind, ha? I have not ’scaped drowning to be afeard now of your four legs. Or it hath been said, “As proper a man as ever went on four legs cannot make him give ground,” and it shall be said so again while Stephano breathes at' nostrils.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$What’s going on? Do we have devils on the island? Are you playing tricks on me by showing me savages and uncivilized men from the Indies, ha? I didn’t survive a shipwreck so I could be scared of your four legs now. I’ll never run away from any ordinary man who walks on four legs like the rest of us.$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$The spirit torments me. Oh!
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$The spirit is torturing me. Oh!

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$This is some monster of the isle with four legs who hath got, as I take it, an ague. Where the devil should he learn our language? I will give him some relief if it be but for that. If I can recover him and keep him tame and get to Naples with him, he’s a present for any emperor that ever trod on neat’s leather.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$This is some monster of the island, with four legs, who seems to me to have some kind of ache. How the hell does he know our language? I’ll help out, if only because he speaks the same language as me. If I can cure him from his fever and tame him, and get him back to Naples, he’d make a great present for any emperor.

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Do not torment me, prithee. I’ll bring my wood home faster.
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Don’t hurt me, please. I promise I’ll carry the wood faster.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$He’s in his fit now and does not talk after the wisest. He shall taste of my bottle. If he have never drunk wine afore, it will go near to remove his fit. If I can recover him and keep him tame, I will not take too much for him. He shall pay for him that hath him, and that soundly.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$He’s having a fit and talking nonsense. I’ll give him some liquor. If he’s never drunk it before, it’ll help soothe his fever. If I can tame him, I’ll charge as much as I can get for him. He’ll bring a lot of money to the person who owns him, that’s for sure.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Thou dost me yet but little hurt. Thou wilt anon, I know it by thy trembling. Now Prosper works upon thee.
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$You haven’t hurt me much yet, but you will soon, I can tell by your trembling. Prospero sent you here.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$(trying to give CALIBAN drink)$NEWLINE$(trying to give$NEWLINE$drink)$NEWLINE$Come on your ways. Open your mouth. Here is that which will give language to you, cat. Open your mouth. This will shake your shaking, I can tell you, and that soundly. You cannot tell who’s your friend. Open your chaps again.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$(trying to make CALIBAN drink) Come on, open your mouth. This’ll help you talk. Open up. This’ll stop you from trembling—I can tell you that for sure. (CALIBAN drinks) You don’t even know who your friends are. Open up that mouth again.$NEWLINE$(trying to make$NEWLINE$drink)$NEWLINE$($NEWLINE$drinks)

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$I should know that voice. It should be—But he is drowned, and these are devils. Oh, defend me!
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$I almost recognize that voice. It’s—But he’s drowned, and these guys are devils. Oh, God help me!

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Four legs and two voices—a most delicate monster. His forward voice now is to speak well of his friend. His backward voice is to utter foul speeches and to detract. If all the wine in my bottle will recover him, I will help his ague. Come.$NEWLINE$CALIBAN drinks$NEWLINE$drinks$NEWLINE$Amen! I will pour some in thy other mouth.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Four legs and two voices—a very special monster. One voice speaks well and talks about his friend. The other voice is harsh and abusive. I can charge even more for this. If it takes all the wine in my bottle, I’ll cure him. Come on. CALIBAN drinks That’s good! Now I’ll pour some in your other mouth.$NEWLINE$drinks

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Stephano!
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Stephano!

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Doth thy other mouth call me? Mercy, mercy! This is a devil, and no monster. I will leave him. I have no long spoon.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Is your other mouth calling my name? Mercy, mercy! This isn’t a monster, it’s a devil. I’ll leave him alone. I have no interest in getting mixed up with the devil.

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Stephano! If thou beest Stephano, touch me and speak to me. For I am Trinculo—be not afeard—thy good friend Trinculo.
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Stephano! If you’re Stephano, touch me and speak to me. I’m Trinculo—don’t be scared—your good friend Trinculo.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$If thou beest Trinculo, come forth. I’ll pull thee by the lesser legs. If any be Trinculo’s legs, these are they. (pulls TRINCULO out from under the gaberdine)$NEWLINE$(pulls$NEWLINE$out from under the gaberdine)
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$If you’re Trinculo, then come out. I’ll pull on these smaller legs. If any legs here are Trinculo’s, these are. (he pulls TRINCULO out from under the cloak) Well,$NEWLINE$(he pulls$NEWLINE$out from under the cloak)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Thou art very Trinculo indeed! How camest thou to be the siege of this mooncalf? Can he vent Trinculos?
paragraphs.translated: what do you know, you are Trinculo! How did you end up as this monster’s dung? Does he crap Trinculos?$NEWLINE$are

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$I took him to be killed with a thunderstroke. But art thou not drowned, Stephano? I hope now thou art not drowned. Is the storm overblown? I hid me under the dead mooncalf’s gaberdine for fear of the storm. And art thou living, Stephano? O Stephano, two Neapolitans ’scaped! (dances STEPHANO about)$NEWLINE$(dances$NEWLINE$about)
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$I thought he was dead, struck by lightning. But aren’t you drowned, Stephano? I hope you’re not drowned. Has the storm passed? I hid under this monster’s cloak to get out of the storm. Are you really alive, Stephano? Oh, Stephano, two men from Naples survived! (TRINCULO dances STEPHANO around.)$NEWLINE$($NEWLINE$dances$NEWLINE$around.)

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Prithee, do not turn me about. My stomach is not constant.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Please stop turning me around. My stomach’s a little upset.

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$(aside) These be fine things, an if they be not sprites. That’s a brave god and bears celestial liquor. I will kneel to him.$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$(to himself) These are beautiful creatures, if they’re not spirits. He’s a good god, who brings liquor from the heavens. I will worship him.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$(to TRINCULO) How didst thou ’scape? How camest thou hither? Swear by this bottle how thou camest hither. I escaped upon a butt of sack which the sailors heaved o'erboard, by this bottle, which I made of the bark of a tree with mine own hands since I was cast ashore.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$(to TRINCULO) How did you survive? How did you get here? Tell me the truth, swear on this bottle of wine. I made it out of tree bark after I washed ashore. I myself floated here on a barrel of wine that the sailors tossed overboard.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$(to STEPHANO) I’ll swear upon that bottle to be thy true subject, for the liquor is not earthly.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$(to STEPHANO) I’ll swear by that wine bottle to be your true subject. You must be a god, since your liquor is out of this world.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$(to TRINCULO) Here. Swear then how thou escapedst.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$(to TRINCULO) Here. Swear, and tell me how you survived.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Swum ashore, man, like a duck. I can swim like a duck, I’ll be sworn.
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$I swam ashore like a duck. I can swim like a duck, I swear.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Here, kiss the book. Though thou canst swim like a duck, thou art made like a goose.
paragraphs.translated:
STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Here,
kiss the Bible and swear. You may swim like a duck, but you look more like a goose.$NEWLINE$kiss the Bible$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO drinks$NEWLINE$TRINCULO
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO drinks.$NEWLINE$TRINCULO

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$O Stephano, hast any more of this?
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Oh Stephano, do you have any more of that wine?

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$The whole butt, man. My cellar is in a rock by th' seaside where my wine is hid.—How now, mooncalf? How does thine ague?
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$I’ve got the whole barrel, man. I live in a cave by the seaside, where I keep the barrel hidden.—Hey, monster, how’s your fever?

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Hast thou not dropped from heaven?
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$You come from heaven, don’t you?

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Out o' th' moon, I do assure thee. I was the man i' the moon when time was.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$No, from the moon, I’m telling you. I used to be the man in the moon a long time ago.

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$I have seen thee in her and I do adore thee. My mistress showed me thee and thy dog and thy bush.
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Oh, I’ve seen you in the moon, and I worship you. My mistress showed me you in the moon and your dog and your bush.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Come, swear to that, kiss the book. I will furnish it anon with new contents, swear.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Come on, swear to it. Kiss the Bible and swear it. I’m going to fill the bottle up again soon.

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN drinks$NEWLINE$CALIBAN
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN drinks.$NEWLINE$CALIBAN

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$By this good light, this is a very shallow monster. I afeard of him! A very weak monster. The man i' th' moon! A most poor credulous monster.—Well drawn, monster, in good sooth!
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$When you get a good look at him, you see he’s not much of a monster. I can’t believe I was scared of him! A pretty pathetic monster. The man in the moon! What a poor, gullible monster.—That was a nice big gulp, monster!

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$(to STEPHANO) I’ll show thee every fertile inch o' th' island.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$And I will kiss thy foot. I prithee, be my god.
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$(to STEPHANO) I’ll show you every inch of the island, and I’ll kiss your feet. I beg you, please be my god.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$By this light, a most perfidious and drunken monster.$NEWLINE$When ’s god’s asleep, he’ll rob his bottle.
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$What a lying, drunken monster. When his god falls asleep, the monster will snatch his wine bottle.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$(to STEPHANO) I’ll kiss thy foot. I’ll swear myself thy subject.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$(to STEPHANO) I’ll kiss your feet. I’ll vow to be your faithful subject.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Come on then. Down, and swear.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Come on, then. Get down and swear it.

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$I shall laugh myself to death at this puppy-headed monster.$NEWLINE$A most scurvy monster. I could find in my heart to beat him—
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$I’m going to laugh myself to death over this silly monster. A rotten, foolish monster. I could find it in my heart to beat him—

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$(to CALIBAN) Come, kiss.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Come on, kiss my feet.

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$But that the poor monster’s in drink. An abominable monster!
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Except the poor monster’s drunk. An awful monster!

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$I’ll show thee the best springs. I’ll pluck thee berries.$NEWLINE$I’ll fish for thee and get thee wood enough.$NEWLINE$A plague upon the tyrant that I serve!$NEWLINE$I’ll bear him no more sticks, but follow thee,$NEWLINE$Thou wondrous man.
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$I’ll show you where to get fresh water. I’ll pick berries for you. I’ll fish for you and get you plenty of firewood. The tyrant I’m serving now can go to hell! I won’t get any more wood for him. I’m serving you now, you wonderful man.

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$A most ridiculous monster, to make a wonder of a poor drunkard.
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$What a silly monster, to think a poor drunk is wonderful.

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$(to STEPHANO) I prithee, let me bring thee where crabs grow.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$And I with my long nails will dig thee pignuts,$NEWLINE$Show thee a jay’s nest, and instruct thee how$NEWLINE$To snare the nimble marmoset. I’ll bring thee$NEWLINE$To clustering filberts, and sometimes I’ll get thee$NEWLINE$Young scamels from the rock. Wilt thou go with me?
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$(to STEPHANO) I beg you, let me show where you can find crabs to eat. I’ll use my long fingernails to dig edible roots for you, find you a bird’s nest, and teach you how to catch a nimble monkey. I’ll take you to clusters of hazelnuts, and sometimes I’ll catch birds for you on the rocks. Will you come with me?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$I prithee now, lead the way without any more talking.— Trinculo, the king and all our company else being drowned, we will inherit here.—Here, bear my bottle.—Fellow Trinculo, we’ll fill him by and by again.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Show us the way without further delay.—Trinculo, since the king and all our comrades are drowned, we’re the heirs of this place.—Here, carry my wine bottle.—Trinculo, my buddy, we’ll get that bottle refilled soon enough.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$(sings drunkenly)$NEWLINE$(sings drunkenly)$NEWLINE$Farewell, master! Farewell, farewell.$NEWLINE$Farewell, master! Farewell, farewell
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$(sings drunkenly)$NEWLINE$(sings drunkenly)$NEWLINE$Goodbye, master! Goodbye, goodbye.$NEWLINE$Goodbye, master! Goodbye, goodbye

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$A howling monster, a drunken monster.
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$A loud-mouthed, drunken monster.

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$No more dams I’ll make for fish,$NEWLINE$No more dams I’ll make for fish$NEWLINE$Nor fetch in firing$NEWLINE$Nor fetch in firing$NEWLINE$At requiring,$NEWLINE$At requiring$NEWLINE$Nor scrape trencher, nor wash dish.$NEWLINE$Nor scrape trencher, nor wash dish$NEWLINE$'Ban, 'Ban, Ca-caliban$NEWLINE$'Ban, 'Ban, Ca-caliban$NEWLINE$Has a new master. Get a new man.$NEWLINE$Has a new master. Get a new man$NEWLINE$Freedom, high-day, high-day, freedom, freedom, high-day, freedom!$NEWLINE$Freedom, high-day, high-day, freedom, freedom, high-day, freedom!
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$I won’t build you any more dams to catch fish,$NEWLINE$I won’t build you any more dams to catch fish$NEWLINE$Or fetch you firewood when you order me to,$NEWLINE$Or fetch you firewood when you order me to$NEWLINE$Or clean the plates, or wash dishes.$NEWLINE$Or clean the plates, or wash dishes$NEWLINE$'Ban, 'ban, Ca-caliban$NEWLINE$'Ban, 'ban, Ca-caliban$NEWLINE$Has a new master. So get a new servant.$NEWLINE$Has a new master. So get a new servant$NEWLINE$Freedom, what a wonderful day, wonderful day, freedom, freedom, wonderful day, freedom!$NEWLINE$Freedom, what a wonderful day, wonderful day, freedom, freedom, wonderful day, freedom!

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$O brave monster! Lead the way.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Good monster! Show us the way.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter FERDINAND bearing a log$NEWLINE$FERDINAND
paragraphs.translated: FERDINAND enters, carrying a log.$NEWLINE$FERDINAND

paragraphs.original: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$There be some sports are painful, and their labor$NEWLINE$Delight in them sets off. Some kinds of baseness$NEWLINE$Are nobly undergone. And most poor matters$NEWLINE$Point to rich ends. This my mean task$NEWLINE$Would be as heavy to me as odious, but$NEWLINE$The mistress which I serve quickens what’s dead$NEWLINE$And makes my labors pleasures. Oh, she is$NEWLINE$Ten times more gentle than her father’s crabbed,$NEWLINE$And he’s composed of harshness. I must remove$NEWLINE$Some thousands of these logs and pile them up,$NEWLINE$Upon a sore injunction. My sweet mistress$NEWLINE$Weeps when she sees me work, and says such baseness$NEWLINE$Had never like executor. I forget,$NEWLINE$But these sweet thoughts do even refresh my labors,$NEWLINE$Most busiest when I do it.
paragraphs.translated: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$Some games are painful, but their discomfort makes them more fun. Some kinds of lowly activities are done for noble reasons. And you can do poor things that lead to rich results. This hard work would be boring and nasty to me, but I’m working for a mistress who makes me enjoy my labor. Oh, she’s ten times nicer than her father is mean, and he’s the height of crabbiness. I have thousands of logs to take away and pile up, on strict orders from him. My sweet darling cries when she sees me work and tells me that such a wonderful man never performed such lowly tasks before. These sweet thoughts relieve me and refresh me, especially when I’m slaving away busily.

paragraphs.original: Enter MIRANDA, and PROSPERO unseen$NEWLINE$MIRANDA$NEWLINE$PROSPERO
paragraphs.translated: MIRANDA enters, followed by PROSPERO at a distance, unobserved.$NEWLINE$MIRANDA$NEWLINE$PROSPERO

paragraphs.original: MIRANDA$NEWLINE$Alas now, pray you,$NEWLINE$Work not so hard. I would the lightning had$NEWLINE$Burnt up those logs that you are enjoined to pile!$NEWLINE$Pray, set it down and rest you. When this burns,$NEWLINE$'Twill weep for having wearied you. My father$NEWLINE$Is hard at study. Pray now, rest yourself.$NEWLINE$He’s safe for these three hours.
paragraphs.translated: MIRANDA$NEWLINE$Now, please, I beg you, don’t work so hard. I wish the lightning had burned up all those logs that you’ve been ordered to stack! Please put that log down and rest a while. When this wood burns, it’ll weep for making you tired. My father’s studying hard, so he won’t see you. So please rest. We’re safe from my father for at least three hours.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$O most dear mistress,$NEWLINE$The sun will set before I shall discharge$NEWLINE$What I must strive to do.
paragraphs.translated: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$Oh, my dear mistress, I won’t be able to finish this work until sunset at the earliest.

paragraphs.original: MIRANDA$NEWLINE$If you’ll sit down,$NEWLINE$I’ll bear your logs the while. Pray, give me that.$NEWLINE$I’ll carry it to the pile.
paragraphs.translated: MIRANDA$NEWLINE$If you sit down, I’ll carry your logs a while. Please give me that. I’ll take it over to the pile.

paragraphs.original: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$No, precious creature.$NEWLINE$I had rather crack my sinews, break my back,$NEWLINE$Than you should such dishonor undergo$NEWLINE$While I sit lazy by.
paragraphs.translated: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$No, my darling, I’d rather strain all my muscles and break my back than let you do work like this while I lounge around nearby.

paragraphs.original: MIRANDA$NEWLINE$It would become me$NEWLINE$As well as it does you, and I should do it$NEWLINE$With much more ease, for my good will is to it$NEWLINE$And yours it is against.
paragraphs.translated: MIRANDA$NEWLINE$I’d be as right for the job as you are, and I’d do it more easily, since I’d have good will on my side.

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$(aside)    Poor worm, thou art infected!$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$This visitation shows it.
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$(to himself) You poor weak thing, you’re in love! I can see it clearly now.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: MIRANDA$NEWLINE$You look wearily.
paragraphs.translated: MIRANDA$NEWLINE$You look tired.

paragraphs.original: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$No, noble mistress. 'Tis fresh morning with me$NEWLINE$When you are by at night. I do beseech you—$NEWLINE$Chiefly that I might set it in my prayers—$NEWLINE$What is your name?
paragraphs.translated: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$No, noble mistress, I’m as fresh as morning when you’re near me, even at night. I beg you to tell me your name so I can use it in my prayers.

paragraphs.original: MIRANDA$NEWLINE$Miranda.—O my father,$NEWLINE$I have broke your hest to say so!
paragraphs.translated: MIRANDA$NEWLINE$Miranda.—Oh father, I’ve disobeyed you by telling him that!

paragraphs.original: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$Admired Miranda!$NEWLINE$Indeed the top of admiration, worth$NEWLINE$What’s dearest to th' world! Full many a lady$NEWLINE$I have eyed with best regard and many a time
paragraphs.translated: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$Miranda—the very name means “admired!” You are indeed admired, more than anything else in the world! I’ve looked at many ladies with pleasure, and been

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Th' harmony of their tongues hath into bondage$NEWLINE$Brought my too diligent ear. For several virtues$NEWLINE$Have I liked several women. Never any$NEWLINE$With so full soul but some defect in her$NEWLINE$Did quarrel with the noblest grace she owed$NEWLINE$And put it to the foil. But you, O you,$NEWLINE$So perfect and so peerless, are created$NEWLINE$Of every creature’s best.
paragraphs.translated: seduced by the sweet nothings they said to me. I’ve liked several women for their good qualities, but there was something wrong with each one that blotted her excellent qualities and cancelled them out. But with you it’s different. You’re perfect, without a rival in the world, made up of the best qualities of every creature.

paragraphs.original: MIRANDA$NEWLINE$I do not know$NEWLINE$One of my sex, no woman’s face remember—$NEWLINE$Save, from my glass, mine own. Nor have I seen$NEWLINE$More that I may call men than you, good friend,$NEWLINE$And my dear father. How features are abroad$NEWLINE$I am skill-less of, but, by my modesty,$NEWLINE$The jewel in my dower, I would not wish$NEWLINE$Any companion in the world but you,$NEWLINE$Nor can imagination form a shape$NEWLINE$Besides yourself to like of. But I prattle$NEWLINE$Something too wildly, and my father’s precepts$NEWLINE$I therein do forget.
paragraphs.translated: MIRANDA$NEWLINE$I’ve never known any woman or seen a woman’s face—except my own in the mirror. And I’ve never met any men besides you and my father. I have no idea what people look like in other places, but I swear by my modesty, which I value above everything else, that I’d never want any companion in the world but you. I can’t even imagine one. But listen to me chattering like crazy, and father always told me not to.

paragraphs.original: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$I am in my condition$NEWLINE$A prince, Miranda—I do think, a king;$NEWLINE$I would, not so!—and would no more endure$NEWLINE$This wooden slavery than to suffer$NEWLINE$The flesh-fly blow my mouth. Hear my soul speak.$NEWLINE$The very instant that I saw you did$NEWLINE$My heart fly to your service, there resides$NEWLINE$To make me slave to it, and for your sake$NEWLINE$Am I this patient log-man.
paragraphs.translated: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$I’m a prince by birth, Miranda—maybe even a king now; though I wish I weren’t—and normally I wouldn’t put up with carrying these logs any more than I’d let flies breed in my mouth. But I’ll tell you something from my soul. The second I saw you, my heart rushed to serve you and be your slave, so here I am now, a patient log-man.

paragraphs.original: MIRANDA$NEWLINE$Do you love me?
paragraphs.translated: MIRANDA$NEWLINE$Do you love me?

paragraphs.original: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$O heaven, O earth, bear witness to this sound$NEWLINE$And crown what I profess with kind event
paragraphs.translated: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$Oh heaven, oh earth, witness what I’m about to say, and reward me if I tell the truth! If I’m lying, then

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: If I speak true! If hollowly, invert$NEWLINE$What best is boded me to mischief! I$NEWLINE$Beyond all limit of what else i' th' world$NEWLINE$Do love, prize, honor you.
paragraphs.translated: destroy all my prospects in life! More than anything else in the world, I love you, value you, and honor you.

paragraphs.original: MIRANDA$NEWLINE$I am a fool$NEWLINE$To weep at what I am glad of.
paragraphs.translated: MIRANDA$NEWLINE$Look at me crying—what a fool I am to cry at what makes me happy.

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$(aside)     Fair encounter$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$Of two most rare affections! Heavens rain grace$NEWLINE$On that which breeds between 'em!
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$(to himself) What a pleasant meeting between two people truly in love! May heaven bless the feelings growing between them!$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$Wherefore weep you?
paragraphs.translated: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$Why are you crying?

paragraphs.original: MIRANDA$NEWLINE$At mine unworthiness, that dare not offer$NEWLINE$What I desire to give, and much less take$NEWLINE$What I shall die to want. But this is trifling,$NEWLINE$And all the more it seeks to hide itself$NEWLINE$The bigger bulk it shows. Hence, bashful cunning,$NEWLINE$And prompt me, plain and holy innocence!$NEWLINE$I am your wife if you will marry me.$NEWLINE$If not, I’ll die your maid. To be your fellow$NEWLINE$You may deny me, but I’ll be your servant$NEWLINE$Whether you will or no.
paragraphs.translated: MIRANDA$NEWLINE$I’m crying at how unworthy I am to give you what I want to give you and to take what I’m dying to have. But it’s a waste of time to say so. The more I try to hide what I’m feeling, the bigger it gets. Oh, stop being so bashful and tricky, Miranda, just be straightforward and innocent! I’ll be your wife if you’ll have me. Otherwise, I’ll die a virgin, devoted to you. You can refuse to make me your spouse, but I’ll be your servant whether you want me to or not.

paragraphs.original: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$My mistress, dearest, and I thus humble ever.
paragraphs.translated: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$You’ll be my wife, dearest, and I’ll serve you forever.

paragraphs.original: MIRANDA$NEWLINE$My husband, then?
paragraphs.translated: MIRANDA$NEWLINE$Will you be my husband, then?

paragraphs.original: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$Ay, with a heart as willing$NEWLINE$As bondage e'er of freedom. Here’s my hand.
paragraphs.translated: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$Yes, with a heart more eager to bear a husband’s responsibilities than a slave ever wanted freedom. Take my hand, darling.

paragraphs.original: MIRANDA$NEWLINE$And mine, with my heart in ’t. And now farewell$NEWLINE$Till half an hour hence.
paragraphs.translated: MIRANDA$NEWLINE$Here’s my hand, and my heart. And now goodbye. I’ll see you again in half an hour.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT
