paragraphs.original: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$A thousand thousand!
paragraphs.translated: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$A million goodbyes to you.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt FERDINAND and MIRANDA severally$NEWLINE$FERDINAND$NEWLINE$MIRANDA
paragraphs.translated: MIRANDA and FERDINAND exit in opposite directions.$NEWLINE$MIRANDA$NEWLINE$FERDINAND

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$So glad of this as they I cannot be,$NEWLINE$Who are surprised withal. But my rejoicing$NEWLINE$At nothing can be more. I’ll to my book,$NEWLINE$For yet ere supper-time must I perform$NEWLINE$Much business appertaining.
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$I can’t be as happy as they are at this moment, but nothing could make me any happier. Now it’s time to get back to my studying, since I have a lot of serious business to take care of before dinner.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CALIBAN, STEPHANO, and TRINCULO$NEWLINE$CALIBAN$NEWLINE$STEPHANO$NEWLINE$TRINCULO
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN, STEPHANO, and TRINCULO enter.$NEWLINE$CALIBAN$NEWLINE$STEPHANO$NEWLINE$TRINCULO

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Tell not me. When the butt is out, we will drink water. Not a drop before. Therefore bear up and board 'em.—Servant- monster, drink to me.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Don’t tell me that. When the barrel’s empty, we’ll drink water. Not one drop sooner. Therefore, drink up.—Servant-monster, drink a toast to me.

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$“Servant-monster”? The folly of this island. They say there’s but five upon this isle. We are three of them. If th' other two be brained like us, the state totters.
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$“Servant monster”? What a crazy island this is. They say there are only five people on it. We’re three of them. If the other two are as loopy as we are, our country’s in bad shape.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Drink, servant-monster, when I bid thee. Thy eyes are almost set in thy head.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Drink when I order you, servant-monster. Your eyes look like they’ve sunk into your head.

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Where should they be set else? He were a brave monster indeed, if they were set in his tail.
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Where else should his eyes be, if not in his head? He’d be quite a monster if his eyes were in his tail.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$My man-monster hath drowned his tongue in sack. For my part, the sea cannot drown me. I swam, ere I could recover the shore, five and thirty leagues off and on. By this light, thou shalt be my lieutenant, monster, or my standard.
paragraphs.translated:
STEPHANO$NEWLINE$My man—monster is so drunk he can’t talk. As for me, no liquid can harm me, neither booze nor the whole sea itself. Before I could get to shore, I swam thirty-five
leagues in it and still survived.—Monster, you’ll be my lieutenant, or my flag-bearer.$NEWLINE$leagues$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Your lieutenant, if you list. He’s no standard.
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Lieutenant is better. He’s not standing straight enough to hold a flag.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$We’ll not run, Monsieur Monster.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$We’re not going to run in our army, Monsieur Monster.

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Nor go neither. But you’ll lie like dogs, and yet say nothing neither.
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Or walk either. You’ll just lie there like sleeping dogs and say nothing.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Mooncalf, speak once in thy life, if thou beest a good mooncalf.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Monster sweetie, be a good monster and just speak once.

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$How does thy honor? Let me lick thy shoe.$NEWLINE$(indicates TRINCULO) I’ll not serve him. He’s not valiant.$NEWLINE$(indicates$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$How is your Highness? Let me lick your shoe. (he points to TRINCULO) I’ll never serve that guy there. He’s not courageous like you.$NEWLINE$(he points to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$(to CALIBAN) Thou liest, most ignorant monster. I am in case to justle a constable. Why, thou deboshed fish, thou, was there ever man a coward that hath drunk so much sack as I today? Wilt thou tell a monstrous lie, being but half a fish and half a monster?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$(to CALIBAN) You’re a liar, you ignorant monster. I’m courageous. I could shake up a police officer right now. You drunken fish, you, how could you call me a coward after all the booze I’ve drunk today? Do you tell such monstrous lies because you’re half fish and half monster?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$(to STEPHANO)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Lo, how he mocks me! Wilt thou let him, mylord?
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$(to STEPHANO) Look how he’s making fun of me! Will you let him talk to me like, my lord?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$“Lord,” quoth he? That a monster should be such a natural!
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$“Lord,” he calls you? What an idiot that monster is!

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$(to STEPHANO)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Lo, lo, again! Bite him to death, I prithee.
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$(to STEPHANO) There he goes again! Please, bite him to death, I’m begging you.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Trinculo, keep a good tongue in your head. If you prove a mutineer, the next tree. The poor monster’s my subject and he shall not suffer indignity.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Trinculo, speak politely. If you mutiny against me, I’ll hang you from the next tree. This poor monster is my subject, and I will not allow him to be insulted.

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$I thank my noble lord. Wilt thou be pleased to hearken once again to the suit I made to thee?
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Thank you, my noble lord. Now would you please listen once again to the request I made to you earlier?

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Marry, will I. Kneel and repeat it. I will stand, and so shall$NEWLINE$Trinculo.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Indeed, I will. Kneel and tell me again. I’ll stand, and so will Trinculo.

paragraphs.original: Enter ARIEL, invisible$NEWLINE$ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL enters, invisible.$NEWLINE$ARIEL

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$(kneeling) As I told thee before, I am subject to a tyrant, a sorcerer that by his cunning hath cheated me of the island.$NEWLINE$(kneeling)
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$(kneeling) As I told you before, I’m enslaved to a tyrant, a magician who tricked me with magic spells and took my island from me.$NEWLINE$(kneeling)

paragraphs.original: ARIEL$NEWLINE$Thou liest.
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL$NEWLINE$You lie.

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$(to TRINCULO) Thou liest, thou jesting monkey, thou! I would my valiant master would destroy thee. I do not lie.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$(to TRINCULO) You’re the liar, you big fat monkey. I wish my courageous master would kill you. I’m not lying.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Trinculo, if you trouble him any more in ’s tale, by this hand, I will supplant some of your teeth.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Trinculo, if you interrupt him any more, I swear I’ll knock some teeth out of your head.

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Why, I said nothing.
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$I didn’t say anything.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Mum, then, and no more. Proceed.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Okay, just stay quiet. Go on.

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$I say, by sorcery he got this isle.$NEWLINE$From me he got it. If thy greatness will$NEWLINE$Revenge it on him—for I know thou darest,$NEWLINE$But this thing dare not—
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$I was telling you he used witchcraft to take this island. He stole it from me. If your highness is willing, take revenge on him for that—because I know you’re brave enough, I don’t dare to—

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$That’s most certain.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$That’s for sure.

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Thou shalt be lord of it and I’ll serve thee.
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$You’ll be lord of the island then, and I’ll be your servant.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$How now shall this be compassed?$NEWLINE$Canst thou bring me to th' party?
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$And how would we go about doing that? Can you bring me to him?

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Yea, yea, my lord. I’ll yield him thee asleep,$NEWLINE$Where thou mayst knock a nail into his head.
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Yes, yes, my lord. I’ll take you to where he sleeps, and you can pound a nail into his head.

paragraphs.original: ARIEL$NEWLINE$Thou liest. Thou canst not.
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL$NEWLINE$You lie. You can’t do that.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$What a pied ninny’s this!—Thou scurvy patch!—$NEWLINE$I do beseech thy greatness, give him blows$NEWLINE$And take his bottle from him. When that’s gone,$NEWLINE$He shall drink naught but brine, for I’ll not show him$NEWLINE$Where the quick freshes are.
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$What an idiot this guy is!—You’re a rotten piece of work!—I beg your highness, beat him up and take his wine bottle from him. When he loses that, he’ll be drinking salt water, since I’ll never tell him where the freshwater springs are.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Trinculo, run into no further danger. Interrupt the monster one word further, and, by this hand, I’ll turn my mercy out o' doors and make a stockfish of thee.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Trinculo, watch out. If you interrupt this monster with one more word, I’ll beat you like a piece of salted fish.

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Why, what did I? I did nothing. I’ll go farther off.
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$What did I do? I didn’t do anything. I need to get away from you.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Didst thou not say he lied?
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Didn’t you call him a liar?

paragraphs.original: ARIEL$NEWLINE$Thou liest.
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL$NEWLINE$You lie.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$(to TRINCULO) Do I so? Take thou that.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(beats TRINCULO)$NEWLINE$(beats$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$As you like this, give me the lie another time.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$(to TRINCULO) Oh, I did? Take that, then. (he beats TRINCULO) If you want more beatings like that, just accuse me of lying again.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(he beats$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$I did not give the lie. Out o' your wits and hearing too? A pox o' your bottle! This can sack and drinking do. A murrain on your monster, and the devil take your fingers!
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$I didn’t accuse you of lying. Are you out of your mind and deaf too? Damn your wine! This is what happens when you drink too much. Your monster can go to hell, and you can too!

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Ha, ha, ha!
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Ha, ha, ha!

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Now, forward with your tale.—Prithee, stand farther off.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Now go ahead and tell me the rest of your story.—Please go stand farther away.

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Beat him enough. After a little time,$NEWLINE$I’ll beat him too.
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Beat him up. After a little while, I’ll beat him too.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Stand farther.—Come, proceed.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Stand farther away.— Come on, continue your story.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Why, as I told thee, ’tis a custom with him,$NEWLINE$I' th' afternoon to sleep. There thou mayst brain him,$NEWLINE$Having first seized his books; or with a log$NEWLINE$Batter his skull; or paunch him with a stake;$NEWLINE$Or cut his weasand with thy knife. Remember$NEWLINE$First to possess his books, for without them$NEWLINE$He’s but a sot, as I am, nor hath not$NEWLINE$One spirit to command. They all do hate him$NEWLINE$As rootedly as I. Burn but his books.$NEWLINE$He has brave utensils—for so he calls them—$NEWLINE$Which when he has a house, he’ll deck withal.$NEWLINE$And that most deeply to consider is$NEWLINE$The beauty of his daughter. He himself$NEWLINE$Calls her a nonpareil. I never saw a woman,$NEWLINE$But only Sycorax my dam and she.$NEWLINE$But she as far surpasseth Sycorax$NEWLINE$As great’st does least.
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Just as I told you, he usually sleeps in the afternoon. At that time you can smash in his skull after seizing his books; or you can bash his skull with a log; or you can stab him in the belly; or cut his windpipe. Just remember to grab his books first, since without them he’s just a poor fool like me, and can’t command a single spirit. All the spirits hate him as much as I do. Be sure to burn his magic books. He has some wonderful home furnishings—that’s what he calls them—that he’ll use to decorate his house when he gets one. The most important thing for you to think about is how beautiful his daughter is. He says she has no equal. I never saw a woman except her and Sycorax, my mother. But Miranda is so much more beautiful, you can’t even compare the two.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Is it so brave a lass?
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Is she really that wonderful?

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Ay, lord. She will become thy bed, I warrant.$NEWLINE$And bring thee forth brave brood.
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Yes, my lord. She’ll look good in your bed, and she’ll produce some fine children too.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Monster, I will kill this man. His daughter and I will be king and queen—save our graces!—and Trinculo and thyself shall be viceroys.—Dost thou like the plot, Trinculo?
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Monster, I’ll kill this man. His daughter and I will be king and queen—God protect us!—and you and Trinculo will be our governors.—Do you like that idea, Trinculo?

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Excellent.
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Excellent.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Give me thy hand. I am sorry I beat thee. But while thou livest, keep a good tongue in thy head.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Give me your hand. I’m sorry I hit you. But try to control your speech.

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Within this half hour will he be asleep. Wilt thou destroy him then?
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$In a half an hour he’ll be asleep. Will you kill him then?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Ay, on mine honor.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Yes, I swear.

paragraphs.original: ARIEL$NEWLINE$(aside) This will I tell my master.$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL$NEWLINE$(to himself) I’ll tell my master this.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Thou makest me merry. I am full of pleasure.$NEWLINE$Let us be jocund. Will you troll the catch$NEWLINE$You taught me but whilere?
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$You make me so happy. I’m full of joy. Let’s be light-hearted. Will you sing the tune you taught me just a little while ago?

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$At thy request, monster, I will do reason, any reason.—$NEWLINE$Come on, Trinculo, let us sing.$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$Flout 'em and scout 'em,$NEWLINE$Flout 'em and scout 'em$NEWLINE$And scout 'em and flout 'em.$NEWLINE$And scout 'em and flout 'em$NEWLINE$Thought is free.$NEWLINE$Thought is free
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$I’ll do anything you ask, monster, anything reasonable.—Come on, Trinculo, let’s sing. (he sings)$NEWLINE$(he sings)$NEWLINE$Dismiss 'em and ziss 'em$NEWLINE$Dismiss 'em and ziss 'em$NEWLINE$And diss 'em and dismiss 'em.$NEWLINE$And diss 'em and dismiss 'em$NEWLINE$Thought is free.$NEWLINE$Thought is free

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$That’s not the tune.
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$That’s not the tune I had in mind.

paragraphs.original: ARIEL plays the tune on a tabor and pipe$NEWLINE$ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL plays the tune on a drum and a pipe.$NEWLINE$ARIEL

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$What is this same?
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$What’s this song?

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$This is the tune of our catch, played by the picture of Nobody.
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$That’s the melody, played by Nobody.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$If thou beest a man, show thyself in thy likeness. If thou beest a devil, take ’t as thou list.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$(to the invisible musician) If you’re a man, then let us see what you look like. If you’re a devil, then go to hell.$NEWLINE$(to the invisible musician)

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$O, forgive me my sins!
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Oh, forgive all my sins!

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$He that dies pays all debts.—I defy thee!—Mercy upon us!
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Dead men have to pay their debts.—I challenge you!—God help us.

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Art thou afeard?
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Are you scared?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$No, monster, not I.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$No, monster, not me.

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Be not afeard. The isle is full of noises,$NEWLINE$Sounds, and sweet airs that give delight and hurt not.$NEWLINE$Sometimes a thousand twangling instruments$NEWLINE$Will hum about mine ears, and sometime voices$NEWLINE$That, if I then had waked after long sleep,$NEWLINE$Will make me sleep again. And then, in dreaming,$NEWLINE$The clouds methought would open and show riches$NEWLINE$Ready to drop upon me, that when I waked$NEWLINE$I cried to dream again.
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Don’t be scared. This island is full of noises, strange sounds and sweet melodies that make you feel good and don’t hurt anyone. Sometimes I hear a thousand twanging instruments hum at my ears, and sometimes voices that send me back to sleep even if I had just woken up—and then I dreamed of clouds opening up and dropping such riches on me that when I woke up, I cried because I wanted to dream again.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$This will prove a brave kingdom to me, where I shall have my music for nothing.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$This’ll be a wonderful kingdom to live in, where they play music for free.

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$When Prospero is destroyed.
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$As soon as you kill Prospero.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$That shall be by and by. I remember the story.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$That’ll happen soon enough. I remember the plan.

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$The sound is going away. Let’s follow it, and after do our work.
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$The sound is going away. But let’s follow it, and then do our dirty work afterward.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Lead, monster; we’ll follow. I would I could see this taborer. He lays it on.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Lead us, monster; we’ll follow. I wish I could see this invisible drummer. He really plays well.

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Wilt come? I’ll follow, Stephano.
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$I’m right behind you, Stephano. Are you coming monster?

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ALONSO, SEBASTIAN, ANTONIO, GONZALO, ADRIAN, FRANCISCO, and others$NEWLINE$ALONSO$NEWLINE$SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$ANTONIO$NEWLINE$GONZALO$NEWLINE$ADRIAN$NEWLINE$FRANCISCO
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO, SEBASTIAN, ANTONIO, GONZALO, ADRIAN, FRANCISCO, and others enter.$NEWLINE$ALONSO$NEWLINE$SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$ANTONIO$NEWLINE$GONZALO$NEWLINE$ADRIAN$NEWLINE$FRANCISCO

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$(to ALONSO) By 'r lakin, I can go no further, sir.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$My old bones ache. Here’s a maze trod indeed$NEWLINE$Through forthrights and meanders. By your patience,$NEWLINE$I needs must rest me.
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$I swear, I can’t go any further, sir. My old bones are tired. We’re wandering in a maze. If you don’t mind, I need to rest a bit.

paragraphs.original: ALONSO$NEWLINE$Old lord, I cannot blame thee,$NEWLINE$Who am myself attached with weariness$NEWLINE$To th' dulling of my spirits. Sit down and rest.$NEWLINE$Even here I will put off my hope and keep it$NEWLINE$No longer for my flatterer. He is drowned$NEWLINE$Whom thus we stray to find, and the sea mocks$NEWLINE$Our frustrate search on land. Well, let him go.
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO$NEWLINE$I can’t blame you, old lord. I’m so tired myself that it’s bringing me down. Sit down and rest. I’m losing hope. The one we’re looking for is dead. We’re searching on land, but he’s lost in the sea. We have to give up and let him go.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$(aside to SEBASTIAN) I am right glad that he’s so out of hope.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Do not for one repulse forego the purpose$NEWLINE$That you resolved t' effect.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only SEBASTIAN can hear) I’m glad he’s so depressed. Don’t back out of our plan just because it didn’t work the first time.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$(aside to ANTONIO)  The next advantage$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Will we take throughly.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only ANTONIO can hear) The next chance we get, we’ll do the deed.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$(aside to SEBASTIAN) Let it be tonight,$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$For now they are oppressed with travel. They$NEWLINE$Will not, nor cannot, use such vigilance$NEWLINE$As when they are fresh.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only SEBASTIAN can hear) Let’s do it tonight. The men are so tired from traveling that they can’t be as careful as they are when they’re fresh.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: Solemn and strange music
paragraphs.translated: Solemn and strange music is heard.

paragraphs.original: Enter PROSPERO on the top, invisible$NEWLINE$PROSPERO
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO enters above, invisible.$NEWLINE$PROSPERO

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$(aside to ANTONIO) I say, tonight. No more.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only ANTONIO can hear) Yes, tonight. No more talking about this now.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: ALONSO$NEWLINE$What harmony is this? My good friends, hark!
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO$NEWLINE$What’s that music? My friends, listen.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$Marvelous sweet music!
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$What marvelous music!

paragraphs.original: Enter several strange shapes, bringing in a banquet They dance about it with gentle actions of salutations, and, inviting the king and the others to eat, they depart
paragraphs.translated: Several strange shapes enter, bringing in a banquet table and dancing around it with graceful, welcoming movements. After inviting the king and the others to eat, they leave.

paragraphs.original: ALONSO$NEWLINE$Give us kind keepers, heavens! What were these?
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO$NEWLINE$Heaven help us! What were those things?

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$A living drollery. Now I will believe$NEWLINE$That there are unicorns, that in Arabia$NEWLINE$There is one tree, the phoenix' throne, one phoenix$NEWLINE$At this hour reigning there.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$A puppet show in real life. Now I’ll believe that unicorns exist, and that there’s a tree in Arabia where the phoenix lives.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I’ll believe both$NEWLINE$And what does else want credit, come to me,$NEWLINE$And I’ll be sworn ’tis true. Travelers ne'er did lie,$NEWLINE$Though fools at home condemn 'em.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Me too. And anything else that’s hard to believe, just ask me and I’ll swear it’s true. Travelers have never told lies, no matter what the fools at home accuse them of.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$If in Naples$NEWLINE$I should report this now, would they believe me?$NEWLINE$If I should say, I saw such islanders—$NEWLINE$For, certes, these are people of the island—$NEWLINE$Who, though they are of monstrous shape, yet note,$NEWLINE$Their manners are more gentle-kind than of$NEWLINE$Our human generation you shall find$NEWLINE$Many—nay, almost any.
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$If I told them about this back in Naples, would they believe me? I’d tell them that I saw natives like these—since they must be natives—who are graceful and well-mannered even if they’re monstrous to look at, kinder than most human beings you might find— kinder than almost any human.

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$(aside)  Honest lord,$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$Thou hast said well, for some of you there present$NEWLINE$Are worse than devils.
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$(to himself) My good lord, you’re absolutely right, since some of you are worse than devils.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ALONSO$NEWLINE$I cannot too much muse$NEWLINE$Such shapes, such gesture, and such sound, expressing,$NEWLINE$Although they want the use of tongue, a kind$NEWLINE$Of excellent dumb discourse.
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO$NEWLINE$I can’t stop being amazed by these shapes, sounds, and gestures, which express, even without saying anything, a wonderful kind of silent language.

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$(aside)   Praise in departing.$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$(to himself) Time to go.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: FRANCISCO$NEWLINE$They vanished strangely.
paragraphs.translated: FRANCISCO$NEWLINE$They vanished strangely.

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$No matter, since$NEWLINE$They have left their viands behind, for we have stomachs.$NEWLINE$Will ’t please you taste of what is here?
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$It’s all right, since they left their food behind, and we’re hungry. Would you like to taste the banquet?

paragraphs.original: ALONSO$NEWLINE$Not I.
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO$NEWLINE$Not me.

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$Faith, sir, you need not fear. When we were boys,$NEWLINE$Who would believe that there were mountaineers$NEWLINE$Dewlapped like bulls, whose throats had hanging at 'em$NEWLINE$Wallets of flesh, or that there were such men$NEWLINE$Whose heads stood in their breasts?—which now we find$NEWLINE$Each putter-out of five for one will bring us$NEWLINE$Good warrant of.
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$I assure you, sir, there’s nothing to be afraid of. When we were boys, who’d believe that there were mountain people with rolls of skin around their necks, with their throats hanging down? Or that there were men with heads in their chests?—Nowadays travelers commonly report that these things exist.

paragraphs.original: ALONSO$NEWLINE$I will stand to and feed,$NEWLINE$Although my last. No matter, since I feel$NEWLINE$The best is past. Brother, my lord the duke,$NEWLINE$Stand to and do as we.
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO$NEWLINE$I’ll start eating, even if this is my last supper. It’s all right, since the best part of my life was over anyway. Brother, Duke, please have some food.

paragraphs.original: Thunder and lightning
paragraphs.translated: Thunder and lightning.

paragraphs.original: Enter ARIEL, like a harpy, claps his wings upon the table, and, with a quaint device, the banquet vanishes$NEWLINE$ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL enters in the form of a harpy ARIEL flaps his wings on the table, and the banquet vanishes from the table$NEWLINE$ARIEL$NEWLINE$ARIEL

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ARIEL$NEWLINE$(to ALONSO, ANTONIO, and SEBASTIAN )$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$You are three men of sin, whom Destiny,$NEWLINE$That hath to instrument this lower world$NEWLINE$And what is in ’t, the never-surfeited sea$NEWLINE$Hath caused to belch up you—and on this island$NEWLINE$Where man doth not inhabit, you ’mongst men$NEWLINE$Being most unfit to live. I have made you mad,$NEWLINE$And even with suchlike valor men hang and drown$NEWLINE$Their proper selves. (some of the courtiers draw their swords)$NEWLINE$(some of the courtiers draw their swords)$NEWLINE$You fools, I and my fellows$NEWLINE$Are ministers of fate. The elements$NEWLINE$Of whom your swords are tempered may as well$NEWLINE$Wound the loud winds or with bemocked-at stabs$NEWLINE$Kill the still-closing waters as diminish$NEWLINE$One dowl that’s in my plume. My fellow ministers$NEWLINE$Are like invulnerable. If you could hurt,$NEWLINE$Your swords are now too massy for your strengths$NEWLINE$And will not be uplifted. But remember—$NEWLINE$For that’s my business to you—that you three$NEWLINE$From Milan did supplant good Prospero,$NEWLINE$Exposed unto the sea, which hath requit it,$NEWLINE$Him and his innocent child. For which foul deed$NEWLINE$The powers—delaying, not forgetting—have$NEWLINE$Incensed the seas and shores, yea, all the creatures,$NEWLINE$Against your peace.—Thee of thy son, Alonso,$NEWLINE$They have bereft, and do pronounce by me$NEWLINE$Lingering perdition, worse than any death$NEWLINE$Can be at once, shall step by step attend$NEWLINE$You and your ways; whose wraths to guard you from—$NEWLINE$Which here, in this most desolate isle, else falls$NEWLINE$Upon your heads—is nothing but hearts' sorrow$NEWLINE$And a clear life ensuing.
paragraphs.translated:
ARIEL$NEWLINE$(to ALONSO, ANTONIO, and SEBASTIAN) The three of you are sinners, and Destiny made the sea belch you up onto this island—where no men live, since none of you deserve to live. I’ve driven you crazy, and many mad people are driven to kill themselves in desperation. (some of the courtiers draw their swords) Listen, you fools, my fellow
harpies and I carry out Fate’s orders. Your swords are useless against us—you’d be more successful swinging them at the empty air, or stabbing at water, than trying to cut off even one of my feathers. My two companions are just as invulnerable as I am. Even if you had the power to hurt us, you’d find your swords far too heavy to lift. But remember—and it’s my job to remind you of this—that in Milan the three of you stole Prospero’s throne and threw him and his innocent child into the sea, which has now taken revenge on you. To punish you for this horrible crime, the higher powers—delaying their punishment, not forgetting about it—have stirred up the seas and all the creatures of earth against you.—They’ve taken your only son from you, Alonso, and they’ve ordered me to destroy you slowly, in a way worse than sudden death could ever be. I’ll stay with you every step of your way. The only way to protect yourselves from the angry higher powers—which are ready to fall upon your head on this empty island—is for you to be sincerely sorry in your hearts for what you’ve done, and to live innocent lives from this time forward.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(some of the courtiers draw their swords)$NEWLINE$harpies$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ARIEL vanishes in thunder$NEWLINE$ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL vanishes in thunder.$NEWLINE$ARIEL

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Then, to soft music enter the shapes again and dance, with mocks and mows, and carrying out the table
paragraphs.translated: The shapes enter again, accompanied by soft music. Dancing with mocking gestures and grimaces, they carry out the banquet table.

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$(aside) Bravely the figure of this harpy hast thou$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$Performed, my Ariel. A grace it had, devouring.$NEWLINE$Of my instruction hast thou nothing bated$NEWLINE$In what thou hadst to say.—So with good life$NEWLINE$And observation strange, my meaner ministers$NEWLINE$Their several kinds have done. My high charms work$NEWLINE$And these mine enemies are all knit up$NEWLINE$In their distractions. They now are in my power,$NEWLINE$And in these fits I leave them while I visit$NEWLINE$Young Ferdinand, whom they suppose is drowned,$NEWLINE$And his and mine loved darling.
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$(to himself) You’ve played the role of harpy very well, my Ariel. You were fierce but graceful. You said everything I told you to say.—In the same lifelike way, and with the same attention to detail, my lower-ranking servants have done what they were supposed to do. My magic powers are all in full swing, and my enemies are confused and running around in circles. They’re under my control, and I’m keeping them in their crazy fits while I go visit Ferdinand, whom they think has drowned, and the young woman he and I both love.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Exit PROSPERO above$NEWLINE$PROSPERO
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO exits on a platform overhead.$NEWLINE$PROSPERO

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$(to ALONSO) I' th' name of something holy, sir, why stand you$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$In this strange stare?
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$(to ALONSO) For the love of God, sir, why are you standing here staring into space like this?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ALONSO$NEWLINE$Oh, it is monstrous, monstrous.$NEWLINE$Methought the billows spoke and told me of it,$NEWLINE$The winds did sing it to me, and the thunder,$NEWLINE$That deep and dreadful organ pipe, pronounced$NEWLINE$The name of Prosper. It did bass my trespass.$NEWLINE$Therefore my son i' th' ooze is bedded, and$NEWLINE$I’ll seek him deeper than e'er plummet sounded$NEWLINE$And with him there lie mudded.
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO$NEWLINE$Oh, it’s horrible, horrible. I thought the clouds were talking to me, the winds were singing to me, and the thunder, like an awful organ pipe, roared Prospero’s name. It sang about my crimes. Because of my crimes my son is dead on the ocean floor. I’ll go join him there, going down deeper than any anchor ever sank, and lie with him dead in the mud.

paragraphs.original: Exit ALONSO$NEWLINE$ALONSO
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO exits.$NEWLINE$ALONSO

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$But one fiend at a time,$NEWLINE$I’ll fight their legions o'er.
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$I’ll fight every one of these devils if I have to, one at a time.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I’ll be thy second.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I’ll back you up.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt SEBASTIAN and ANTONIO$NEWLINE$SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$ANTONIO
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN and ANTONIO exit.$NEWLINE$SEBASTIAN$NEWLINE$ANTONIO

paragraphs.original: GONZALO$NEWLINE$All three of them are desperate. Their great guilt,$NEWLINE$Like poison given to work a great time after,$NEWLINE$Now 'gins to bite the spirits. I do beseech you$NEWLINE$That are of suppler joints, follow them swiftly$NEWLINE$And hinder them from what this ecstasy$NEWLINE$May now provoke them to.
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO$NEWLINE$All three of them are crazy with despair. Their guilt is finally starting to gnaw at them, like a slow-acting poison. Those of you who are young and active, I beg you to follow them and keep them from doing the crazy things their guilt might push them to do.

paragraphs.original: ADRIAN$NEWLINE$Follow, I pray you.
paragraphs.translated: ADRIAN$NEWLINE$Follow them, please.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt omnes
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter PROSPERO, FERDINAND, and MIRANDA$NEWLINE$PROSPERO$NEWLINE$FERDINAND$NEWLINE$MIRANDA
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO, FERDINAND, and MIRANDA enter.$NEWLINE$PROSPERO$NEWLINE$FERDINAND$NEWLINE$MIRANDA

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$(to FERDINAND) If I have too austerely punished you,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Your compensation makes amends, for I$NEWLINE$Have given you here a third of mine own life—$NEWLINE$Or that for which I live—who once again$NEWLINE$I tender to thy hand. All thy vexations$NEWLINE$Were but my trials of thy love and thou$NEWLINE$Hast strangely stood the test. Here, afore heaven,$NEWLINE$I ratify this my rich gift. O Ferdinand,$NEWLINE$Do not smile at me that I boast of her,$NEWLINE$For thou shalt find she will outstrip all praise$NEWLINE$And make it halt behind her.
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$(to FERDINAND) If I’ve punished you too harshly, I’m ready to make it up to you now, since I’ve given you a third of my life—everything I live for—my daughter Miranda. I put her in your hands. All the trouble I put you through was to test your love for her, and you’ve passed the test remarkably well. As heaven is my witness, I give you this valuable gift. Oh Ferdinand, don’t smile at me for bragging about Miranda, for you’ll see soon enough that she outshines any praise of her.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$I do believe it$NEWLINE$Against an oracle.
paragraphs.translated:
FERDINAND$NEWLINE$I’d believe it even if
oracles told me differently.$NEWLINE$oracles$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Then as my gift and thine own acquisition$NEWLINE$Worthily purchased, take my daughter. But$NEWLINE$If thou dost break her virgin knot before$NEWLINE$All sanctimonious ceremonies may$NEWLINE$With full and holy rite be ministered,$NEWLINE$No sweet aspersion shall the heavens let fall$NEWLINE$To make this contract grow, but barren hate,$NEWLINE$Sour-eyed disdain, and discord shall bestrew$NEWLINE$The union of your bed with weeds so loathly$NEWLINE$That you shall hate it both. Therefore take heed,$NEWLINE$As Hymen’s lamps shall light you.
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Then take my daughter, both as my gift to you and as something you have earned. But if you have sex with her before the marriage ceremony takes place, the heavens will not bless your relationship, but will overwhelm you with hate, contempt, and discord, and will poison your marriage bed so that you both grow to loathe it. So be careful, and make sure you respect the holy institution of marriage.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$As I hope$NEWLINE$For quiet days, fair issue, and long life,$NEWLINE$With such love as ’tis now, the murkiest den,$NEWLINE$The most opportune place, the strong’st suggestion,$NEWLINE$Our worser genius can shall never melt$NEWLINE$Mine honor into lust to take away$NEWLINE$The edge of that day’s celebration$NEWLINE$When I shall think, or Phoebus' steeds are foundered,$NEWLINE$Or night kept chained below.
paragraphs.translated: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$I want peace, good kids, and a long life. To protect the love I cherish, I won’t be tempted by any opportunity to forget my honor and give in to lust. I refuse to give up the joys of my wedding day, when I’ll be so eager for my first night of love that I’ll wonder whether evening will ever come.

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Fairly spoke.$NEWLINE$Sit then and talk with her. She is thine own.—$NEWLINE$What, Ariel! My industrious servant, Ariel!
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$You’ve said it well. So have a seat and talk to her. She’s yours.—Come, Ariel! My trusty servant, Ariel!

paragraphs.original: Enter ARIEL$NEWLINE$ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL enters.$NEWLINE$ARIEL

paragraphs.original: ARIEL$NEWLINE$What would my potent master? Here I am.
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL$NEWLINE$What does my powerful master wish for? I’m here.

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Thou and thy meaner fellows your last service$NEWLINE$Did worthily perform, and I must use you$NEWLINE$In such another trick. Go bring the rabble,$NEWLINE$O'er whom I give thee power, here to this place.$NEWLINE$Incite them to quick motion, for I must$NEWLINE$Bestow upon the eyes of this young couple$NEWLINE$Some vanity of mine art. It is my promise,$NEWLINE$And they expect it from me.
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$You and your fellow spirits did your last assignment well, and now I need your help again. Go bring them all here; I give you power over them. Make them act quickly. I have to give this young couple here a small display of my magic powers. I’ve promised them I would, and they’re expecting it.

paragraphs.original: ARIEL$NEWLINE$Presently?
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL$NEWLINE$Right now?

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Ay, with a twink.
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Yes, right away.

paragraphs.original: ARIEL$NEWLINE$Before you can say “Come” and “Go,”$NEWLINE$And breathe twice and cry “So, so!”$NEWLINE$Each one, tripping on his toe,
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL$NEWLINE$Before you can say “Come” and “Go,”$NEWLINE$And breathe twice, and shout “So, so!”$NEWLINE$Each one of your servants will rush here,

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Will be here with mop and mow.$NEWLINE$Do you love me, master, no?
paragraphs.translated: Tripping over his own toes, making funny faces.$NEWLINE$Do you love me, master? No?

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Dearly my delicate Ariel. Do not approach$NEWLINE$Till thou dost hear me call.
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$I love you dearly, Ariel. Don’t come near till you hear me call you.

paragraphs.original: ARIEL$NEWLINE$Well, I conceive.
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL$NEWLINE$All right, I understand.

paragraphs.original: Exit ARIEL$NEWLINE$ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL exits.$NEWLINE$ARIEL

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$(to FERDINAND) Look thou be true. Do not give dalliance$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Too much the rein. The strongest oaths are straw$NEWLINE$To th' fire i' th' blood. Be more abstemious,$NEWLINE$Or else, goodnight your vow.
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$(to FERDINAND) Make sure you behave honorably. Don’t go too far with her. If you let yourself get stirred up, you’ll forget your promise of good behavior. Calm yourself down or you’ll forget your vow.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$I warrant you, sir,$NEWLINE$The white cold virgin snow upon my heart$NEWLINE$Abates the ardor of my liver.
paragraphs.translated: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$I assure you, sir, the tender love I feel in my heart is stronger than the sexual passions stirring down below.

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Well.—$NEWLINE$Now come, my Ariel! Bring a corollary,$NEWLINE$Rather than want a spirit. Appear and pertly!—
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Good.—Now come, Ariel! Better to have an extra servant on hand than be understaffed. Appear before me now quickly—

paragraphs.original: Soft music
paragraphs.translated: Soft music plays.

paragraphs.original: No tongue. All eyes! Be silent.
paragraphs.translated: No talking. Just watch! Be quiet.

paragraphs.original: Enter IRIS$NEWLINE$IRIS
paragraphs.translated: IRIS enters.$NEWLINE$IRIS

paragraphs.original: IRIS$NEWLINE$Ceres, most bounteous lady, thy rich leas$NEWLINE$Of wheat, rye, barley, vetches, oats, and peas;$NEWLINE$Thy turfy mountains, where live nibbling sheep,$NEWLINE$And flat meads thatched with stover, them to keep;$NEWLINE$Thy banks with pionèd and twillèd brims,
paragraphs.translated: IRIS$NEWLINE$I am the rainbow-bearing messenger sent by my mistress Juno—the Queen of the Sky. I have come to announce that Juno has asked you, Ceres, goddess of the fields and the earth, to leave your rich farms of wheat, rye, barley, oats, and peas, the hills where the

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Which spongy April at thy hest betrims$NEWLINE$To make cold nymphs chaste crowns; and thy broom groves,$NEWLINE$Whose shadow the dismissèd bachelor loves,$NEWLINE$Being lass-lorn; thy pole-clipped vineyard;$NEWLINE$And thy sea-marge, sterile and rocky hard,$NEWLINE$Where thou thyself dost air—the Queen o' th' Sky,$NEWLINE$Whose watery arch and messenger am I,$NEWLINE$Bids thee leave these, and with her sovereign grace,
paragraphs.translated: sheep nibble, the furrows that April covers with flowers for nymphs to make crowns with. You must leave the groves where the disappointed bachelor lurks, rejected by his love, and the well-pruned vineyards, and the rocky seashore.

paragraphs.original: JUNO descends above$NEWLINE$JUNO
paragraphs.translated: JUNO enters above the stage and slowly begins to descend.$NEWLINE$JUNO

paragraphs.original: Here on this grass plot, in this very place,$NEWLINE$To come and sport. Her peacocks fly amain.$NEWLINE$Approach, rich Ceres, her to entertain.
paragraphs.translated: You must leave these places and hurry here to this grassy spot, to entertain Juno.

paragraphs.original: Enter CERES$NEWLINE$CERES
paragraphs.translated: CERES enters.$NEWLINE$CERES

paragraphs.original: CERES$NEWLINE$Hail, many-colored messenger, that ne'er$NEWLINE$Dost disobey the wife of Jupiter;$NEWLINE$Who with thy saffron wings upon my flowers$NEWLINE$Diffusest honey drops, refreshing showers;$NEWLINE$And with each end of thy blue bow dost crown$NEWLINE$My bosky acres and my unshrubbed down,$NEWLINE$Rich scarf to my proud earth. Why hath thy queen$NEWLINE$Summoned me hither to this short-grassed green?
paragraphs.translated: CERES$NEWLINE$Greetings to you, rainbow messenger, who never disobeys Juno, wife of Jupiter; with your golden wings you sprinkle dewdrops and refreshing showers on my flowers, and arch your colored bow over my wooded fields and grassy meadows, like a beautiful scarf to decorate my earth. Why has your queen, Juno, called me here to this grassy spot?

paragraphs.original: IRIS$NEWLINE$A contract of true love to celebrate,$NEWLINE$And some donation freely to estate$NEWLINE$On the blessed lovers.
paragraphs.translated: IRIS$NEWLINE$To celebrate a marriage of true love, and give a gift to the lovers.

paragraphs.original: CERES$NEWLINE$Tell me, heavenly bow,$NEWLINE$If Venus or her son, as thou dost know,$NEWLINE$Do now attend the queen? Since they did plot$NEWLINE$The means that dusky Dis my daughter got,$NEWLINE$Her and her blind boy’s scandaled company$NEWLINE$I have forsworn.
paragraphs.translated: CERES$NEWLINE$Tell me, rainbow, do you know if either Venus, the goddess of love, or her son, Cupid, is accompanying Queen Juno? Ever since Venus and her blind son plotted a way for the god of the underworld to steal my daughter away for half the year, I swore I’d never speak to them again.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: IRIS$NEWLINE$Of her society$NEWLINE$Be not afraid. I met her deity$NEWLINE$Cutting the clouds towards Paphos, and her son$NEWLINE$Dove-drawn with her. Here thought they to have done$NEWLINE$Some wanton charm upon this man and maid,$NEWLINE$Whose vows are that no bed-right shall be paid$NEWLINE$Till Hymen’s torch be lighted—but in vain.$NEWLINE$Mars’s hot minion is returned again.$NEWLINE$Her waspish-headed son has broke his arrows,$NEWLINE$Swears he will shoot no more, but play with sparrows$NEWLINE$And be a boy right out.
paragraphs.translated: IRIS$NEWLINE$Don’t be afraid of her company. I met Venus as she was with her son on her way to her home on Paphos, in a carriage pulled by doves. They were planning to pull a mischievous trick on Ferdinand and Miranda, who have sworn not to sleep together till their wedding day. But their trick failed. Venus went home again, and her little son broke all his arrows, swearing he’ll never shoot them again, but play with birds like other little boys.

paragraphs.original: CERES$NEWLINE$Highest queen of state,$NEWLINE$Great Juno, comes. I know her by her gait.
paragraphs.translated: CERES$NEWLINE$Great Queen Juno is coming. I know her by her walk.

paragraphs.original: JUNO descends to the stage$NEWLINE$JUNO
paragraphs.translated: JUNO comes down to the stage.$NEWLINE$JUNO

paragraphs.original: JUNO$NEWLINE$How does my bounteous sister? Go with me$NEWLINE$To bless this twain that they may prosperous be,$NEWLINE$And honored in their issue.
paragraphs.translated: JUNO$NEWLINE$How is my generous sister? Come help me bless this couple, so they will be prosperous and have many children.

paragraphs.original: They sing
paragraphs.translated: They sing.

paragraphs.original: JUNO$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$Honor, riches, marriage, blessing,$NEWLINE$Honor, riches, marriage, blessing$NEWLINE$Long continuance, and increasing,$NEWLINE$Long continuance, and increasing$NEWLINE$Hourly joys be still upon you.$NEWLINE$Hourly joys be still upon you$NEWLINE$Juno sings her blessings on you.$NEWLINE$Juno sings her blessings on you
paragraphs.translated: JUNO$NEWLINE$(singing)$NEWLINE$(singing)$NEWLINE$May honor, riches, marriage blessings,$NEWLINE$May honor, riches, marriage blessings$NEWLINE$Long life, and unending joys come to you.$NEWLINE$Long life, and unending joys come to you$NEWLINE$Juno sings her blessings onto you.$NEWLINE$Juno sings her blessings onto you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CERES$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$Earth’s increase, foison plenty,$NEWLINE$Earth’s increase, foison plenty$NEWLINE$Barns and garners never empty,$NEWLINE$Barns and garners never empty$NEWLINE$Vines and clustering bunches growing,$NEWLINE$Vines and clustering bunches growing$NEWLINE$Plants with goodly burden bowing—$NEWLINE$Plants with goodly burden bowing$NEWLINE$Spring come to you at the farthest$NEWLINE$Spring come to you at the farthest$NEWLINE$In the very end of harvest.$NEWLINE$In the very end of harvest$NEWLINE$Scarcity and want shall shun you.$NEWLINE$Scarcity and want shall shun you$NEWLINE$Ceres' blessing so is on you.$NEWLINE$Ceres' blessing so is on you
paragraphs.translated: CERES$NEWLINE$(singing)$NEWLINE$(singing)$NEWLINE$Growing crops and large harvests,$NEWLINE$Growing crops and large harvests$NEWLINE$Barns and silos full of grain,$NEWLINE$Barns and silos full of grain$NEWLINE$Vines heavy with clustered grapes,$NEWLINE$Vines heavy with clustered grapes$NEWLINE$Plants straining under their fruit—$NEWLINE$Plants straining under their fruit—$NEWLINE$May spring follow directly autumn’s harvest,$NEWLINE$May spring follow directly autumn’s harvest$NEWLINE$With none of winter’s hardships to endure,$NEWLINE$With none of winter’s hardships to endure$NEWLINE$You will have plenty and want nothing,$NEWLINE$You will have plenty and want nothing$NEWLINE$Ceres’s blessings on you.$NEWLINE$Ceres’s blessings on you.

paragraphs.original: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$This is a most majestic vision, and$NEWLINE$Harmonious charmingly. May I be bold$NEWLINE$To think these spirits?
paragraphs.translated: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$This is a majestic and harmonious vision. Are these spirits we see before us?

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Spirits, which by mine art$NEWLINE$I have from their confines called to enact$NEWLINE$My present fancies.
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Yes, they’re spirits that I’ve called out of their prisons to perform my whims.

paragraphs.original: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$Let me live here ever.$NEWLINE$So rare a wondered father and a wife$NEWLINE$Makes this place paradise.
paragraphs.translated: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$Let me live here forever. Such a wonderful father-in-law and wife make this place a paradise.

paragraphs.original: JUNO and CERES whisper, and send IRIS on employment$NEWLINE$JUNO$NEWLINE$CERES$NEWLINE$IRIS
paragraphs.translated: JUNO and CERES whisper, then send IRIS on a mission.$NEWLINE$JUNO$NEWLINE$CERES$NEWLINE$IRIS

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Sweet now, silence.$NEWLINE$Juno and Ceres whisper seriously.$NEWLINE$There’s something else to do. Hush and be mute,$NEWLINE$Or else our spell is marred.
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Now be quiet. Juno and Ceres are whispering about something serious. There’s something else to be done. Be silent, or else my magic spell will be broken.

paragraphs.original: IRIS$NEWLINE$You nymphs, called naiads of the windring brooks,$NEWLINE$With your sedged crowns and ever-harmless looks,$NEWLINE$Leave your crisp channels and on this green land$NEWLINE$Answer your summons, Juno does command.
paragraphs.translated: IRIS$NEWLINE$You nymphs who live in the wandering brooks, with seaweed crowns and innocent looks, step out of the water and come join us here on this grassy field. Juno

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Come, temperate nymphs, and help to celebrate$NEWLINE$A contract of true love. Be not too late.
paragraphs.translated: orders you. Come, sweet nymphs, and help us celebrate the wedding of two true lovers. Don’t be late.

paragraphs.original: Enter certain nymphs
paragraphs.translated: Several NYMPHS enter.$NEWLINE$NYMPHS

paragraphs.original: You sunburnt sicklemen of August weary,$NEWLINE$Come hither from the furrow and be merry.$NEWLINE$Make holiday. Your rye-straw hats put on,$NEWLINE$And these fresh nymphs encounter every one$NEWLINE$In country footing.
paragraphs.translated: Now, you tanned fieldworkers who are so tired of August’s labors, get out of the dirt and come rejoice with us here. Put your straw hats on, have some fun, and dance with these young nymphs.

paragraphs.original: Enter certain reapers, properly habited They join with the nymphs in a graceful dance towards the end whereof PROSPERO starts suddenly and speaks.$NEWLINE$PROSPERO
paragraphs.translated: Several fieldworkers enter, dressed appropriately. They join the nymphs in a graceful dance. At the end PROSPERO suddenly acts startled and speaks.$NEWLINE$PROSPERO

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$I had forgot that foul conspiracy$NEWLINE$Of the beast Caliban and his confederates$NEWLINE$Against my life. The minute of their plot$NEWLINE$Is almost come.—Well done. Avoid, no more!
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$I almost forgot about Caliban’s horrible conspiracy to kill me. The moment they planned to act is almost here. (to the spirits)—Good job. Leave now, no more!$NEWLINE$(to the spirits)

paragraphs.original: To a strange, hollow, and confused noise, the spirits heavily vanish
paragraphs.translated: The dancers vanish sadly to a strange, hollow, and confused noise.

paragraphs.original: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$(to MIRANDA) This is strange. Your father’s in some passion$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$That works him strongly.
paragraphs.translated: FERDINAND$NEWLINE$(to MIRANDA) This is strange. Something has really upset your father.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: MIRANDA$NEWLINE$Never till this day$NEWLINE$Saw I him touched with anger so distempered.
paragraphs.translated: MIRANDA$NEWLINE$I’ve never seen him like this. He’s never been as angry and upset as he is now.

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$(to FERDINAND) You do look, my son, in a moved sort,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$As if you were dismayed. Be cheerful, sir.$NEWLINE$Our revels now are ended. These our actors,$NEWLINE$As I foretold you, were all spirits and$NEWLINE$Are melted into air, into thin air.
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$(to FERDINAND) You look like something’s bothering you. Cheer up. Our music-and-dance spectacle is over. These actors were all spirits, as I told you, and they’ve all melted into thin air. And just like the whole empty$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And like the baseless fabric of this vision,$NEWLINE$The cloud-capped towers, the gorgeous palaces,$NEWLINE$The solemn temples, the great globe itself—$NEWLINE$Yea, all which it inherit—shall dissolve,$NEWLINE$And like this insubstantial pageant faded,$NEWLINE$Leave not a rack behind. We are such stuff$NEWLINE$As dreams are made on, and our little life$NEWLINE$Is rounded with a sleep. Sir, I am vexed.$NEWLINE$Bear with my weakness. My old brain is troubled.$NEWLINE$Be not disturbed with my infirmity.$NEWLINE$If you be pleased, retire into my cell$NEWLINE$And there repose. A turn or two I’ll walk$NEWLINE$To still my beating mind.
paragraphs.translated: and ungrounded vision you’ve seen, with its towers topped with clouds, its gorgeous palaces, solemn temples, the world itself—and everyone living in it—which will dissolve just as this illusory pageant has dissolved, leaving not even a wisp of cloud behind. We are all made of dreams, and our life stretches from sleep before birth to sleep after death. Sir, I’m upset. Please put up with my weakness. My old brain is troubled. Don’t be disturbed by my illness. If you like, you can rest a while in my room. I’ll go for a short walk to calm down my feverish mind.

paragraphs.original: FERDINAND, MIRANDA$NEWLINE$We wish your peace.
paragraphs.translated: FERDINAND, MIRANDA$NEWLINE$We hope you feel better and find some peace.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt FERDINAND and MIRANDA$NEWLINE$FERDINAND$NEWLINE$MIRANDA
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Come with a thought. I thank thee, Ariel. Come.
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Come, Ariel—I summon you with a thought. Thank you, Ariel. Come.

paragraphs.original: Enter ARIEL$NEWLINE$ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL enters.$NEWLINE$ARIEL

paragraphs.original: ARIEL$NEWLINE$Thy thoughts I cleave to. What’s thy pleasure?
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL$NEWLINE$I obey all your thoughts. What do you wish?

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Spirit,$NEWLINE$We must prepare to meet with Caliban.
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Spirit, we have to get ready to meet with Caliban.

paragraphs.original: ARIEL$NEWLINE$Ay, my commander. When I presented Ceres,$NEWLINE$I thought to have told thee of it, but I feared$NEWLINE$Lest I might anger thee.
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL$NEWLINE$Yes, my master. When I was putting on the Ceres show, I thought of reminding you about Caliban, but I was afraid of upsetting you.

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Say again, where didst thou leave these varlets?
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Tell me again, where did you leave those lowlifes?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ARIEL$NEWLINE$I told you, sir, they were red-hot with drinking,$NEWLINE$So full of valor that they smote the air$NEWLINE$For breathing in their faces, beat the ground$NEWLINE$For kissing of their feet—yet always bending$NEWLINE$Towards their project. Then I beat my tabor,$NEWLINE$At which, like unbacked colts, they pricked their ears,$NEWLINE$Advanced their eyelids, lifted up their noses$NEWLINE$As they smelt music. So I charmed their ears$NEWLINE$That, calflike, they my lowing followed through$NEWLINE$Toothed briers, sharp furzes, pricking gorse, and thorns,$NEWLINE$Which entered their frail shins. At last I left them$NEWLINE$I' th' filthy-mantled pool beyond your cell,$NEWLINE$There dancing up to th' chins, that the foul lake$NEWLINE$O'erstunk their feet.
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL$NEWLINE$I told you, sir, they were totally drunk, so puffed up with courage that they were getting angry at the air for blowing in their faces, and beating the ground for touching their feet—yet even when drunk, they kept their plan firmly in mind. Then I beat my drum, at which point they pricked up their ears and opened their eyes, looking around for the source of my music. I enchanted them so thoroughly that they followed me through thorn bushes and prickly shrubs that tore up their shins. In the end I left them standing in the smelly pond behind your room, with the stinking water covering them up to their chins.

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$This was well done, my bird.$NEWLINE$Thy shape invisible retain thou still.$NEWLINE$The trumpery in my house, go bring it hither$NEWLINE$For stale to catch these thieves.
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Good job, my little one. Stay invisible. Bring the fancy clothes out of my house, to use as bait to catch these thieves.

paragraphs.original: ARIEL$NEWLINE$I go, I go.
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL$NEWLINE$I’m going, I’m going.

paragraphs.original: Exit ARIEL$NEWLINE$ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL exits.$NEWLINE$ARIEL

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$A devil, a born devil on whose nature$NEWLINE$Nurture can never stick, on whom my pains,$NEWLINE$Humanely taken, all, all lost, quite lost.$NEWLINE$And as with age his body uglier grows,$NEWLINE$So his mind cankers. I will plague them all,$NEWLINE$Even to roaring.
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$He’s a devil, a born devil, who can never be trained. All my attempts to help him, undertaken with the best intentions, have been wasted. As his body grows uglier with age, his mind rots away as well. I’ll torment them all till they roar with pain.

paragraphs.original: Enter ARIEL, loaden with glistering apparel, etc.$NEWLINE$ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL enters, loaded with sparkling clothes.$NEWLINE$ARIEL

paragraphs.original: Come, hang them on this line.
paragraphs.translated: Here, hang them on this clothesline.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CALIBAN, STEPHANO, and TRINCULO, all wet$NEWLINE$CALIBAN$NEWLINE$STEPHANO$NEWLINE$TRINCULO
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN, STEPHANO, and TRINCULO enter all wet.$NEWLINE$CALIBAN$NEWLINE$STEPHANO$NEWLINE$TRINCULO

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Pray you, tread softly, that the blind mole may not hear a foot fall. We now are near his cell.
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Please walk softly, so not even a mole hears us approach. We’re near his room now.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Monster, your fairy, which you say is a harmless fairy, has done little better than played the jack with us.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Hey monster, the spirit you’ve been talking about, the one you call harmless, has been playing tricks on us.

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Monster, I do smell all horse piss, at which my nose is in great indignation.
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Monster, I smell like horse piss, which is making my nose pretty upset.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$So is mine.—Do you hear, monster? If I should take a displeasure against you, look you—
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Mine too.—Are you listening, monster? If I decide to get angry at you, just watch out—

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Thou wert but a lost monster.
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$You’d be done for then, monster.

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Good my lord, give me thy favor still.$NEWLINE$Be patient, for the prize I’ll bring thee to$NEWLINE$Shall hoodwink this mischance. Therefore speak softly.$NEWLINE$All’s hushed as midnight yet.
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$My good lord, I still need you to like me. Be patient, because the prize I’m leading you to will make you forget how smelly you are now. So be quiet. It’s as silent as a graveyard here.

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Ay, but to lose our bottles in the pool—
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$All right, but I can’t get over how we lost our wine bottles in the pond—

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$There is not only disgrace and dishonor in that, monster, but an infinite loss.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Yes, monster, it’s worse than the disgrace of getting drenched and smelly. We lost more than our honor when we lost our wine.

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$That’s more to me than my wetting. Yet this is your harmless fairy, monster.
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$That upsets me much more than getting wet. And you called the fairy creature harmless, monster.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$I will fetch off my bottle, though I be o'er ears for my labor.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$I’ll get my bottle back if it’s the last thing I do.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Prithee, my king, be quiet. Seest thou here,$NEWLINE$This is the mouth o' th' cell. No noise, and enter.$NEWLINE$Do that good mischief which may make this island$NEWLINE$Thine own for ever, and I, thy Caliban,$NEWLINE$For aye thy foot-licker.
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Please, my king, be quiet. Look here, this is the entrance to his room. Be silent and go in. Do the deed that will make this island yours forever, and will make me, Caliban, your worshipful foot-licker.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Give me thy hand. I do begin to have bloody thoughts.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Give me your hand. I’m starting to feel murderous urges.

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$(seeing the apparel)$NEWLINE$(seeing the apparel)$NEWLINE$O King Stephano! O peer, O worthy Stephano, look what a wardrobe here is for thee!
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$(seeing the clothes) Oh, King Stephano! Worthy Stephano, look at the fabulous wardrobe waiting for you here!$NEWLINE$(seeing the clothes)

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Let it alone, thou fool. It is but trash.
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$Leave it alone, you fool. It’s worthless.

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Oh, ho, monster, we know what belongs to a frippery.—$NEWLINE$(puts on a gown) O King Stephano!$NEWLINE$(puts on a gown)
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Oh, monster, we know secondhand clothes when we see them.—(he puts on one of the gowns) Oh, King Stephano!$NEWLINE$(he puts on one of the gowns)

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Put off that gown, Trinculo. By this hand, I’ll have that gown.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Take off that gown, Trinculo. I swear that gown’s for me.

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Thy grace shall have it.
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$You can have it then, your highness.

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$The dropsy drown this fool! What do you mean$NEWLINE$To dote thus on such luggage? Let’s alone,$NEWLINE$And do the murder first. If he awake,$NEWLINE$From toe to crown he’ll fill our skins with pinches,$NEWLINE$Make us strange stuff.
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$To hell with this idiot! Why are you going crazy over these trashy clothes? Leave them alone, and do the murder first. If he wakes up before we kill him, he’ll never stop punishing us.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Be you quiet, monster.—Mistress line, is not this my jerkin? Now is the jerkin under the line.—Now, jerkin, you are like to lose your hair and prove a bald jerkin.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Shut up, monster.—Madame tree, is this jacket for me? Thank you kindly. The tree’s lost its jacket. (he takes a jacket hanging on the tree)—Now the jacket might lose its fur trim and become a bald jacket.$NEWLINE$(he takes a jacket hanging on the tree)—$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Do, do. We steal by line and level, an ’t like your grace.
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Go ahead, take it. We’re stealing things the right way here.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$I thank thee for that jest. Here’s a garment for ’t. Wit shall not go unrewarded while I am king of this country. “Steal by line and level” is an excellent pass of pate. There’s another garment for ’t.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Thank you for that joke. Here, I’ll give you some clothes to show my gratitude. As king of this country I like to reward wit when I hear it. “Stealing things the right way” is a great line. Here’s another jacket to say thanks.

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Monster, come, put some lime upon your fingers, and away with the rest.
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Come here, monster, put some glue on your fingers, and carry away the rest of these clothes for us.

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$I will have none on ’t. We shall lose our time,$NEWLINE$And all be turned to barnacles or to apes$NEWLINE$With foreheads villainous low.
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN$NEWLINE$I won’t have any of this. We’re wasting our time. We’ll miss our chance and be turned into geese or apes with low foreheads.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Monster, lay to your fingers. Help to bear this away where my hogshead of wine is, or I’ll turn you out of my kingdom. Go to, carry this.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Monster, use your fingers. Help us carry these clothes to where my barrel of wine is hidden, or I’ll kick you out of my kingdom. Go on, take them.

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$And this.
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO$NEWLINE$Take these too.

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Ay, and this.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Yes, and these.

paragraphs.original: A noise of hunters heard Enter divers spirits, in shape of dogs and hounds, hunting them about, PROSPERO and ARIEL setting them on$NEWLINE$PROSPERO$NEWLINE$ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: A noise of hunters is heard. Various spirits enter disguised as dogs and hounds, chasing STEPHANO, TRINCULO, and CALIBAN around. PROSPERO and ARIEL follow them, urging the dogs on.$NEWLINE$STEPHANO$NEWLINE$TRINCULO$NEWLINE$CALIBAN$NEWLINE$PROSPERO$NEWLINE$ARIEL

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Hey, Mountain, hey!
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Hey, Mountain, hey!

paragraphs.original: ARIEL$NEWLINE$Silver. There it goes, Silver!
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL$NEWLINE$Silver. There they go, Silver!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Fury, Fury!—There, Tyrant, there. Hark, hark!
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Fury, Fury!—Get over there, Tyrant, there. Listen, listen!

paragraphs.original: Spirits drive out CALIBAN, STEPHANO, and TRINCULO$NEWLINE$CALIBAN$NEWLINE$STEPHANO$NEWLINE$TRINCULO
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN, STEPHANO, and TRINCULO are chased away.$NEWLINE$CALIBAN$NEWLINE$STEPHANO$NEWLINE$TRINCULO

paragraphs.original: Go charge my goblins that they grind their joints$NEWLINE$With dry convulsions, shorten up their sinews$NEWLINE$With agèd cramps, and more pinch-spotted make them$NEWLINE$Than pard or cat o' mountain.
paragraphs.translated: Ariel, go order my goblin servants to make these fellows' bones ache, give them muscle cramps all over, and give them more bruises than leopards have spots.

paragraphs.original: ARIEL$NEWLINE$Hark, they roar.
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL$NEWLINE$Listen they’re howling.

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Let them be hunted soundly. At this hour$NEWLINE$Lie at my mercy all mine enemies.$NEWLINE$Shortly shall all my labors end, and thou$NEWLINE$Shalt have the air at freedom. For a little$NEWLINE$Follow, and do me service.
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Hunt them down. Now all my enemies are at my mercy. Soon all my work will be done, and you’ll be free. Just obey me a little bit longer.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter PROSPERO in his magic robes and ARIEL$NEWLINE$PROSPERO$NEWLINE$ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO enters in his magic robes, with ARIEL.$NEWLINE$PROSPERO$NEWLINE$ARIEL

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Now does my project gather to a head.$NEWLINE$My charms crack not, my spirits obey, and time$NEWLINE$Goes upright with his carriage. How’s the day?
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$My plans are almost at their climax. My spells are working well, my spirits are obeying me, and everything is right on schedule. What time is it?

paragraphs.original: ARIEL$NEWLINE$On the sixth hour, at which time, my lord,$NEWLINE$You said our work should cease.
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL$NEWLINE$It’s after six o'clock, my lord, when you said our work would be finished.

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$I did say so$NEWLINE$When first I raised the tempest. Say, my spirit,$NEWLINE$How fares the king and ’s followers?
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$That’s what I said when I first conjured the tempest. Tell me, spirit, how’s the king and his entourage?

paragraphs.original: ARIEL$NEWLINE$Confined together$NEWLINE$In the same fashion as you gave in charge,$NEWLINE$Just as you left them, all prisoners, sir,$NEWLINE$In the line grove which weather-fends your cell.$NEWLINE$They cannot budge till your release. The king,$NEWLINE$His brother, and yours, abide all three distracted,$NEWLINE$And the remainder mourning over them,$NEWLINE$Brimful of sorrow and dismay. But chiefly$NEWLINE$Him that you termed, sir, “the good old Lord Gonzalo,”$NEWLINE$His tears run down his beard like winter’s drops$NEWLINE$From eaves of reeds. Your charm so strongly works 'em$NEWLINE$That if you now beheld them, your affections$NEWLINE$Would become tender.
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL$NEWLINE$All cooped up together, just as you ordered, all imprisoned in the grove of linden trees that protects your room from bad weather. They can’t move till you release them. The king, his brother, and your brother are all waiting there in a crazed state of mind, and the rest are grieving over them, sad and astonished. “Good old lord Gonzalo,” as you call him, is saddest of all, with tears running down his beard. Your magic spell has such an effect on them that if you saw them now, you’d feel sorry for them.

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Dost thou think so, spirit?
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$Do you think so, spirit?

paragraphs.original: ARIEL$NEWLINE$Mine would, sir, were I human.
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL$NEWLINE$I’d feel sorry for them, if I were human.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$And mine shall.$NEWLINE$Hast thou, which art but air, a touch, a feeling$NEWLINE$Of their afflictions, and shall not myself,$NEWLINE$One of their kind, that relish all as sharply$NEWLINE$Passion as they, be kindlier moved than thou art?$NEWLINE$Though with their high wrongs I am struck to th' quick,$NEWLINE$Yet with my nobler reason 'gainst my fury$NEWLINE$Do I take part. The rarer action is$NEWLINE$In virtue than in vengeance. They being penitent,$NEWLINE$The sole drift of my purpose doth extend$NEWLINE$Not a frown further. Go release them, Ariel.$NEWLINE$My charms I’ll break, their senses I’ll restore,$NEWLINE$And they shall be themselves.
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$I will too. You’re made of air, so if even you feel sorry for them, imagine the pity that I’ll feel, being one of their own human race. I suffer pain just as much as they do, so I’ll sympathize far more than you. Though I’m indignant about their evil deeds, I’ll go with my nobler instincts, which tell me to feel some compassion for them. It’s better to act virtuously rather than vengefully. Now that they’re sorry, I don’t want anything more. Go release them, Ariel. I’ll break my spells and bring them back to their senses, and they’ll feel like themselves again.

paragraphs.original: ARIEL$NEWLINE$I’ll fetch them, sir.
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL$NEWLINE$I’ll go get them, sir.

paragraphs.original: Exit ARIEL$NEWLINE$ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL exits.$NEWLINE$ARIEL

paragraphs.original: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$(tracing a circle on the ground)$NEWLINE$(tracing a circle on the ground)$NEWLINE$Ye elves of hills, brooks, standing lakes, and groves,$NEWLINE$And ye that on the sands with printless foot$NEWLINE$Do chase the ebbing Neptune and do fly him$NEWLINE$When he comes back; you demi-puppets that$NEWLINE$By moonshine do the green sour ringlets make,$NEWLINE$Whereof the ewe not bites; and you whose pastime$NEWLINE$Is to make midnight mushrooms, that rejoice$NEWLINE$To hear the solemn curfew; by whose aid,$NEWLINE$Weak masters though ye be, I have bedimmed$NEWLINE$The noontide sun, called forth the mutinous winds,$NEWLINE$And ’twixt the green sea and the azured vault$NEWLINE$Set roaring war—to th' dread rattling thunder$NEWLINE$Have I given fire, and rifted Jove’s stout oak
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO$NEWLINE$(drawing a large circle on the stage with his staff) I’ve darkened the noontime sun with the aid of you elves who live in the hills and brooks and groves, and you who chase the sea on the beach without leaving footprints in the sand, and run away when the waves come back; and you who make toadstools while the moon shines; who make mushrooms as a hobby after the evening bell has rung. With your help I’ve called up the angry winds, and set the green sea and blue sky at war with each other. I’ve given lightning to the thunderclouds, and burned up Jupiter’s beloved oak.$NEWLINE$(drawing a large circle on the stage with his staff)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: With his own bolt;$NEWLINE$the strong-based promontory$NEWLINE$Have I made shake, and by the spurs plucked up$NEWLINE$The pine and cedar; graves at my command$NEWLINE$Have waked their sleepers, oped, and let 'em forth$NEWLINE$By my so potent art. But this rough magic$NEWLINE$I here abjure, and when I have required$NEWLINE$Some heavenly music, which even now I do,$NEWLINE$To work mine end upon their senses that$NEWLINE$This airy charm is for, I’ll break my staff,$NEWLINE$Bury it certain fathoms in the earth,$NEWLINE$And deeper than did ever plummet sound$NEWLINE$I’ll drown my book.
paragraphs.translated: With his own lightning bolts; I’ve shaken up the sturdy cliffs and uprooted pines and cedars; I’ve opened up graves and awakened the corpses sleeping in them, letting them out with my powerful magic.
